This loop includes a newly added relocation of the Mason-Dixon Trail that follows alongside the creek further. This entire loop is also the first section of the annual 30 mile KTA Superhike. 

From this trailhead you begin at the newly built parking area that has room for about 6 vehicles. You will walk up a wide mowed logging road for a little while until you reach the beautiful Urey Overlook. Here you will find a picnic table and a beautiful view of the Susquehanna River. If you look off to your left you'll see the Safe Harbor Dam.  Continue following the blue blazes of the Mason-Dixon Trail down the mountain from here, be careful not to get confused and turn off onto one of the other local trails. The blue-blazes are quite frequent so if you stop seeing them for a while then you might have made a wrong turn.    

You will eventually cross over Furnace Rd. then hike along the trail some more before finally coming back out onto Furnace Rd. right at the bridge near the campground entrance. You will follow Furnace Rd. here (crossing the bridge) up to the campground office. If you follow the blue blazes along and on the road you will have no problems finding your way. Once you walk up the black-topped path up to where the campground office is, you will need to start disregarding the blue blazes.    

From here you will be off of the Mason-Dixon Trail for a short while. Follow the paved campground's road on the very right and stay far right as you walk up through the campground. You will see several left turns, do not take any of them. Stay on this paved road all the way up the right side of the campground until you reach the very top and it starts to curve left. You will begin to see a fenced in area on your right. After you have passed the fenced in section there will be an old logging rid that you will make a sharp right and back turn onto. It climbs abruptly up the mountain. Follow this logging road for a long while.     

At the top you will pass some newly built Powerline Towers. Pass these and keep going down the dirt road and follow this dirt road as it curves right and then back down to the bottom of the mountain. Once you reach the very bottom you'll be passing a quite interesting homestead  with lots of eclectic looking gardens and roofing made out of old billboard signs. There will be lots of chickens running free here.  

You will now be on Kline Rd.  Follow this road for a good bit. You will cross a small stream and pass some nice little houses. You will eventually catch up with where the the Mason-Dixon Trail crosses this road from your left to your right. Catch the trail here by turning right up into the woods. You will now be following the Blue Blazes again until the end of this hike.   The rest of fairly simple as you follow the Blue Blazes. There will be one point along the creek where you will see a left turn on the trail going up the mountain. If you notice the blaze here turns Red. This is an in-park trail that will also take you back up to the Mason-Dixon Trail where you will be eventually. However, keep right and stay along the Creek and the Blue Blazes will eventually take you back up to the top of the mountain and then crosses Furnace Rd right to the trail-head parking lot.

hits.name: Schenley Park Double Loop
hits.description: This Double loop hike of Schenley Park shows you the majority of the park.

hits.name: Forbidden Drive
hits.description:
This trail can be busy on weekends. The Thomas Mill Covered Bridge is along the way marked with a waypoint.

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of West Northwestern Avenue at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at bridges) or packed gravel, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 4.0 miles heading southbound. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections from about 4.1 through 5.0 miles when going southbound. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Mason-Dixon Trail and Muddy Creek
hits.description:
Beautiful walk along Muddy Creek stream. Trail is mostly narrow with some rockiness but well maintained (blue blazes). There is a tiny lot area at the south entrance (enough for 1-2 cars), but there are also several pull-off areas along Paper Mill road nearby to the south. From the north, you can park at the park on Cold Cabin Road which is about 3/4 of a mile from the trail. Walk down the road with the summer homes on it and look for the blue blaze off to the left.

Caution: Do not park at the bridge. Users have reported that cars parked here are towed almost every weekend.

hits.name: Wind Cave Trail
hits.description:
This trail is located off Bridge Valley Road (PA Route 3038) just south of the town of Pequea. If you are traveling South on 3038 you will follow the river out of Pequea and them there will be a curve in the road leading away from the river. There is an area to pull your car over and park. Some are marked as tow away zones so be careful.

Once parked, there is a trailhead with an orange diagonal double blaze. Follow this trail across a creek and down an access road to the railroad. Watch carefully for the trail leading up the hill on the left. Follow the trail up the hill and check out the amazing views of the river. 

At the end of the trail you will arrive at the Wind Cave. The owner of the Wind Caves property encourages only those with proper experience and/or applicable guides to enter the caves. Please come prepared with appropriate clothing and safety gear. Bring light sources and enter in groups. It is also advisable to notify first responders prior to entering the caves that you are doing so in the event that there is an incident.

hits.name: Hickory Run Blue Trail, Pine Hill and Sand Springs Trail
Chester Valley Trail
hits.description:
This is a well-maintained, wide, paved converted rail trail. There are several road crossings necessary to navigate this trail, so please use caution. 

Accessibility: There are 12 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Indian Run Street at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of King of Prussia Road at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 10 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

hits.name: Wolf's Hollow Park Loop
hits.description:
Wolf's Hollow Park is a 569 acre park in southern Chester County Pa. Featuring diverse terrain from an easy stroll on a paved drive through open fields to rocky wooded climbs. There are 7.9 miles of trials running through the park passing historical sights and the scenic Octorara Creek. This is a foot only park, No bikes or horses, making it a relaxing place for hikers and trail runners. The paved drive is perfect for strollers and those who need a more even path. Dogs are welcome, but they must be leashed.

This route uses the following:
Hill and Hollow Trail
Octararo Ridge Trail
Charcoal Trail
Loop Trail C
Wolf's Hollow Drive
Fenceline Trail
Forest Loop Trail

hits.name: Boyce Mayview Loop
hits.description: Trail offers a variety of scenery from woods, meadows, creeks, and waterfalls.  Very enjoyable suburban park with plenty of trails to keep things interesting.

hits.name: Lehigh Gorge Trail from Jim Thorpe to Abandoned Tunnel
Covered Bridge Trail
hits.description: If you would prefer a shorter version of this route, there is limited parking available in a lot on Park Rd just east of Jordan Creek.

hits.name: River of Rocks Loop
hits.description:
This 6+ loop encompasses parts of the River of Rocks Trail, Golden Eagle Trail, Skyline Trail, Escarpment and the Look Out Trail.  This loop can easily be modified to be shorter or longer in length.  

This trail has its easy and difficult sections. Hawk Mountain Sanctuary ranks the trails as follows. River of Rocks =  Moderate , Golden Eagle = Moderate , Skyline = Most Difficult , Escarpment = Difficult , Look Out = Easy.

hits.name: Blue Marsh Trail
hits.area_name: Blue Marsh Lake National Recreation Area

hits.name: Loyalsock Link Trail and Haystacks and Dutchman Falls
hits.description: This is a great trail with several nice waterfalls and vistas, and supports plenty of water and campsites for users.

hits.name: Washington Crossing State Park Loop
hits.description:
Washington Crossing State Park has a network of around 13 miles. Activities include: hiking, mountain biking, horse-back riding, snowshoeing, and cross-country skiing (in the winter). The terrain is varied but fairly easy. The trails are well-marked. The park supports an interesting assortment of plants and wildlife. 

For a complete trail map, please visit: https://www.state.nj.us/dep/parksandforests/parks/maps/WashingtonCrossingAreaMapFinalDraft.pdf

hits.name: Heritage Trail and Forest Trail Loop
hits.description: This trail route is difficult. Please be prepared and view the route and trails prior to departing. This route follows the following trails: Mineral Springs Loop to Heritage Trail to Connector 9 (C-9) Trail to Wetlands Trail to Heron Trail to Forest Trail back to PA 18 and the parking lot.

hits.name: Sunken Garden Trail
hits.description: A well-marked multi-use trail by the lake. Trail goers navigating with mobility equipment may need assistance throughout this trail due to unpaved and uneven surfaces along with steep (over 8%) grades.

hits.name: Fort Washington Trail
hits.description: This multi-use trail provides opportunities for biking, hiking and cross-country skiing along Wissahickon Creek.

hits.name: Moosic Mountain Loop
hits.area_name: Dick and Nancy Eales Nature Preserve

hits.name: North Trail to L&NE Trail Loop via Appalachian Trail
Haycock Mountain via Top Rock Trail
Garvey Springs Orange Trail to Sunfish Pond
Wissahickon Green Ribbon Trail
hits.description: The Wissahickon Green Ribbon Trail is a suburban trail in southeastern Pennsylvania. The Wissahickon Valley Watershed Association has preserved nearly 200 acres of land immediately adjacent to the Wissahickon Creek through conservation easements or outright ownership of the land.

hits.name: Rocky Ridge and Whiskey Spring via Appalachian Trail
Turkey Hill and Chestnut Grove Trail Loop
hits.description: Mostly open fields for trail. Park has link trail connecting to Turkey Hill trail near northwestern tip and link trail to Enola Trail on southern end.

hits.name: Kings Gap Loop
hits.description:
A cool, inviting trail filled with a lush understory of ferns, this trail winds along the stream and follows the gap in the mountain. The terrain changes to a dry, higher elevation that brings the hiker to the mountaintop. Trails part of this loop are the Scenic Vista trail, Maple Hollow Trail, Forest Heritage trail, Ridge Overlook, Kings Gap Hollow trail, Boundary Trail, Locust Point Trail and Watershed trail. Some of these trails are only used in part to connect to other trails.
  trails.


Follow the Red Blazes.

hits.name: Longfellow, Joyce Kilmer, and Rhododendron Trails
Lake Scranton Loop
hits.description:
This is a well-maintained, family-friendly, paved wooded path around a lake. There are no bikes allowed. There is a wide gravel road from the parking lot about 0.1 miles down to the main paved loop trail. Some of the trail shares the road with vehicles, so using reflective materials, lights, or flagging is recommended for safety.

Accessibility: There does not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Scranton-Pocono Highway at the east end of the trail. However, there is 1 unlined designated accessible space in the gravel parking lot off of Scranton Road at the north end of the trail. It is not van-accessible with striped access aisles. This parking lot has been marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is gravel for the first about 0.1 miles and then paved asphalt. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.1 and 1.5 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: Meeks Run and Oil Well Trail Loop
Devil's Hole Trail
hits.description:
The trails in this area are not marked well, downloading the map ahead of time is recommended. 

There are stream crossings on this route.

hits.name: Allegheny Front Trail
hits.description: Please note many hikers suggest doing this loop clockwise as it is easier.

hits.name: Johnny Reb Trail
hits.description:
The trail begins at the National Cemetery which does not allow dogs. Offline map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that this trail is not well marked. Please consult the Park's map to orient yourself as signage is very poor in this area. 
https://www.nps.gov/gett/planyourvisit/maps.htm

The Johnny Reb Trail is a 4 mile trail, which takes about 2.5 hours to complete.  The trail snakes through historic landmarks and monuments relating to the Battle of Gettysburg and looks at the battle through confederate eyes.  The trail has no access to water along the way so bring plenty to drink.

This trail was set up by the local Boy Scouts of America Council and is meant to be a historical experience through the eyes of Confederate troops.  Booklets are available in the visitor's center for about $2. The booklet contains historic information, directions and spaces for information that can be filled in at each stop, for scouts who wish to earn the patches and medal that go with the trail system.

Unfortunately, while the booklet holds directions and other pertinent information it does not offer a map of the trails.

This trail goes along with the Billy Yank Trail, Eisenhower Farm, Gettysburg Guided Tour, and the Visitors Center.

hits.name: Great Allegheny Passage Trail
hits.description:
Primarily utilized as a long-distance cycling route between Pittsburgh, PA and Cumberland, MD, the G.A.P. (as it is called) connects with the Historic 184.5 mile C&O canal towpath which terminates in Georgetown, Washington D.C. 

A majority of the GAP trail is located on nearly level abandoned rail beds, crushed limestone, and asphalt surfaces. The C&O Canal towpath is a bit rougher dirt and gravel surface with muddy sections after rainfall. Road bikes are not advised.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Commonwealth Place at the northwest end of the trail. 2 of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt, concrete, wooden boardwalks/bridges (with edge barriers and railings), or crushed limestone. It is typically at least 6 feet wide with many wider passing spaces. There are bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily. 

The entire trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved sections. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms along the trail. The Cumberland Visitor Center is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Schenley Park Panther Hollow Trail
hits.description: This trail appears to have staircases, steep to very steep (over 8%) slopes, along with narrow and uneven sections. If navigating with mobility equipment/a wheelchair or stroller use caution.

hits.name: Reed's Run Nature Trail
hits.description: For more information, please review the park's website. https://www.lancasterconservancy.org/preserves/house-rock/

hits.name: Three Rivers Heritage Trail: Monongahela South Shore
Columcille Megalith Park Trail
hits.description: Awesome rock gardens, meditation center, spiritual journey.

hits.name: Mason-Dixon Trail: Otter Creek to Bridgeville
The Haystacks and Dutchman Falls Trail
Lenape Trail and Boone Trail Loop
hits.description: This loop trail connects all major attractions of French Creek, making it an excellent route to see the park. Several portions are steep and rocky so, wear sturdy shoes. Mountain bikes are not allowed near Hopewell Lake.

hits.name: Loyalsock Trail and Link Trail Loop
Ranger Trail
hits.description:
There are an assortment of trail loops in this area. This is the North Eastern part of Codorus State Park. There are plenty of scenic views of the lake as well as an amazing pine tree forest area. The scenery varies quite a bit throughout the different trail loops. The full section is marked with the Letters M (1-26) on them. M stands for main trail, SC = short cut and L = Loop. 

PLEASE NOTE that these are known to local people as the horse trails. So while they are hike able, know that they are trafficked by mostly horses and there is plenty of manure on the trail.

hits.name: Victoria Loop
hits.description: This is a beautiful, well-maintained trail. It is amazing how much work must have gone into building the stairs and other stonework. There is good elevation gain, but it's not too difficult. There are lots of other trails to explore in the valley on the north side of Peter’s Mountain.

hits.name: Quebec Run Outer Loop
hits.description:
This hike takes the long route around the circumference of the Quebec Run Wild Area. Starting closkwise, the Miller Tr. (1 mile) takes you down the hill into the run. You meet the Mill Run Tr. and a short detour across the bridge will take you to the Grist Mill foundations. There are several easy stream crossings and the more difficult ones have bridges. It's 1.5 miles to the bottom of West Rd.

The Tebolt Trail (3.9 miles)  is a newer trail that is a steady climb up the run. There are several challenging stream crossings and in one case the stream has broken its banks and runs down the trail itself for 100 feet.

The Hess Tr. (4.2 miles) has varried terrain with a substantial climb up out of Quebec Run. Legend has it that Confederate raiders hid captured Union gold in a cave above the run and sealed it with a dynamite blast. The "Gold Mine" are numerous pits where searches have dug for the lockbox. No gold has ever been found.

hits.name: Devil’s Falls
hits.description: Park at the industrial park in a stone parking lot and take the trail left. It's a stone road/ATV trail.

hits.name: River Trail
hits.description: Shady, great river views! love the variety of paths to explore here too. The lower river path can flood during/after major weather, and can be muddy after rain. Bring your yucky shoes and have fun!

hits.name: Lorimer Park Loop
hits.description: A leisurely stroll through Lorimer Park and the perimeter of Fox Chase Farm. The hike provides both a decent workout with a few short, steep hills and an opportunity to rest on one of the numerous benches along the trail. There is also a picnic area and restrooms available.

hits.name: Green Lane Park Orange and Perkiomen Trail Loop
Camelback Mountain via Old Railroad Grade, North and South Trails
hits.description: From the gate and parking area along North Rd./Railroad Dr. head east into the woods along the old railroad grade of the former Wilkes-Barre and Eastern railroad. At 1.3 miles reach junction with North Trail Loop. This was the former site of Tannersville Station. A stagecoach road descended to the right on switchbacks to the town in the valley below. Continue straight into deep railroad cut through a spur of the mountain. Trail proceeds along railroad grade through groves of hemlock and rhododendron. At 2.2 miles leave railroad grade and turn left onto North Trail, ascending Camelback Mountain. At 2.4 miles turn right to follow North Trail up the mountain. Ascent becomes rather steep. Reach the Nile Mile ski trail of the Camelback Ski Area at 2.9 miles. The trail follows the ski trail towards the summit. At 3.2 miles the trail reaches the top of Camelback Mountain at Rim Road, a paved road accessible from the base of the ski area. The summit of Camelback Mountain is open and features picnic areas, benches, nature trails and a privy. There are outstanding views north across the Pocono Plateau and south towards the Blue Mountain and Kittatinny Mountain. It can be rather crowded in summer and during good weather. Bear left on Rim Rd and continue for 0.5 miles. Turn left off of road onto Vista Trail then left again onto South Trail. At 4.4 miles come to junction of trails. Turn right onto South Trail, now descending steeply. At 5.4 miles pass junction with North Trail, continue straight. Reach the old railroad grade at 6.0 miles at the former train station site. Turn right and return to parking area along railroad grade.

hits.name: Valley Creek Trail
hits.description: Great trail for a quick morning walk, some elevation, history and natural views.

hits.name: The Pinnacle Via Pinnacle Side Trail
Double Run Nature Trail
hits.description: 1.2-mile loop, more difficult hiking with short, steep sections. White rectangle with green stripe blazes. This trail begins and ends on PA 154 across from the park chapel. It travels trough rich, fertile woodlands along the west branch of Double Run stream.

hits.name: Scenic South Trail to Appalachian Trail via Ashfield Road
hits.description: A nice moderate hike to get to the scenic South Trail off the Appalachian Trail coming from Ashfield Road as opposed to Lehigh Gap. This makes for a 4 mile hike rather than a 9 mile one. This is a lollipop out and back, a little over a mile in along the AT in a wooded setting the Blue Blaze Sout Trail is on the right. Taking it leads to a mile of exposed rocky trail with near constant views to the north and south of the Mountain. The South Trail rejoins the AT after 1.1 miles, making a left on the Appalachian Trail you complete the lollipop portion and the back to Ashfield Road

hits.name: Musser Gap Short Loop
hits.description: Short loop at Musser Gap trailhead.

hits.name: Twin Falls
hits.description:
A great hike along some streams and with water falls State Game Lands #13

Start on the trail along Heberly Run past Twin Falls and Lewsi Falls, at the fork in the stream take the right hand fork.  As you climb follow the trail as it leaves the stream, goes along the crest of the hill and joins Sullivan branch, follow down stream to where it joins Big Run and back to where you left your car.

The hike starts by walking the West stream not Grassy Hollow Road. Once you get to the East side be careful when you are coming up to Ore Run. There is a "road" that you can continue on that brings you out to the main road. You can bailout on this road or you can continue to follow the stream at this point. If you choose to follow the stream you are going to see some amazing water falls. Once you get down to Pigeon Run you will see a beautiful waterfall on your left. Continue for about .25 miles and on your left you will see a small clearing. Follow that clearing up to the top of the access road to finish the last leg of the hike.

hits.name: Pennypack Trail
hits.description:
This is a great path that is partially paved or gravel with an excellent canopy. It is popular for biking, running, and walking. This trail runs from Byberry Road to Pennypack on the Delaware. There are multiple trail entrances. There are several road crossings necessary to fully navigate the trail, so please use caution.

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Byberry Road at the north end of the trail. There are 3 unlined designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of State Road at the south end of the trail. None of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 4.4, 6.1, and 7.3 miles when going south. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type and grade. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Cynwyd Heritage Trail from Manayunk
hits.description:
It seems everyone in Manayunk knows the towpath along the river. Few have found this trail from downtown Manayunk to the Baga Cynwyd SEPTA station, and it's got it all: views over Manayunk, the canal, river, and freeway, a pleasant stream, interpretive signage, access to the historic cemetery, and even a cafe at the end of the trail.

This trail has both paved and unpaved options for paths and a perfect trail for everyone from walkers to runners, tricycles to road bikes.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Dupont Street at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.1 and 0.3 miles when getting on and off the bridge when going south. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Glen Onoko Falls to D&L Trail Loop
Ricketts Bulldozer - Highland Loop
hits.description: The Old Bulldozer Trail is blazed red and considered "More Difficult" on the park website, but the Highland Loop is not blazed. The first mile and a half or so is pretty steep but there are nice views after that.

hits.name: The Pinnacle Via Valley Rim Trail
Gerard Hiking Trail
hits.description:
The Gerard Hiking Trail (GHT) is blazed in yellow paint and the connector trails to cross the creek are blazed in white.  There are many access points since it is a loop. 

There are some amazing vista along this trail along with a few waterfalls. You can backpack this trail but, camping is only allowed at the shelters. The shelters are very nice structures that have built in fireplaces. There is wood available for a donation. 

There are cross connector trails along the trail that will allow you to do smaller loops. Along the trail, you can see a lot of the old equipment used during the oil boom. 

Watch your step! You may encounter rattlesnakes and other wildlife, including bears, on this trail.


The museum is closed on Mondays.

hits.name: East Brandywine Trail
hits.description:
This is a paved route, but there are both paved and dirt trail options in this area and a good amount of shade. There are lots of wildflowers too.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Downingtown Pike at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. There is 1 unlined designated accessible space in the gravel parking lot off of Downington Pike at the north end of the trail. It is not van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is starting at the north end and going south. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section in the first about 0.1 miles when going north. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Springfield Trail
hits.description:
The Springfield Trail is 4.7-mile loop trail through public and private lands in Springfield Township, PA and Nether Providence Township, PA. The trail features a portion in Smedley Park along Crum Creek, as well as portions along Whiskey Run. The trail connects to the Leiper-Smedley trail at it's northern terminus. 

The trail includes many historical features, including Jane Lowne's original Springfield dwelling in a cave, many former mill and industrial sites from the 17 century onward.

hits.name: Rockcores, Garvey Springs, Appalachian, and Douglas Trails Loop
hits.description:
From the trailhead, hike a tenth of a mile north.  On the right-hand side of the road, you will see a gate, and a trail going up.  Climb the trail.  The first area will be grassy, quickly followed by a young forest.  This part of the trail will be  marked by a green dot on a white rectangle mark on tree trunks.  When you intersect with the orange rectangle marked trail, turn left onto it, until you climb to the Appalachian Trail intersection (AT is marked white rectangles).

On the AT turn south (right), and on the next intersection, turn left into a trail that will border the pond, and will start to amaze you with how beautiful this area is.  Keep walking.  You will find a wood road where you turn right and walk for a while until you join the Appalachian trail again, this time traveling north (right).  Here is where you will truly enjoy the pond.  There are several rocky overlooks to the left, where you might want to lunch. 

Once you reach the orange trail you can retrace your path back to the car.

hits.name: White Clay Creek (PennDel Trail)
hits.description: This route is a section of the Mason-Dixon Trail. Hikers can either return on the PennDel Trail from which they came, or loop around on the Charles Bailey Trail on the eastern side of the creek. There are alternate trailheads for this route, as it crosses many roads.

hits.name: Ridley Creek Blue and White Trail loop
hits.description: Nice quick loop through north half of the park

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Peters Mountain to Victoria Trail
Pike 2 Bike (Abandoned Pennsylvania Turnpike)
hits.description:
The route shown on this page starts at the northern terminus of the Pike 2 Bike. There is also a southern terminus with another parking area.

This hike explores a section of America's first long-distance, limited-access highway that was taken out of service in 1968 when the turnpike diverted over and around the mountains instead of through them. There are two dark, damp, and abandoned tunnels that are slowly reverting to nature. The tunnels are dark (in the longer tunnel, neither end is visible from the center) and offer a chilling sensory experience in addition to a cool respite from the heat and exertion outside.

From the east side, it is a short hike to the larger of the two tunnels: Sideling Hill Tunnel. This tunnel is approximately 1.3 miles long with a slight crest in the middle. At approximately 3.5 miles farther on (with some slight rolling hills along the way), hikers will come to Ray's Hill Tunnel, which is about 0.5 miles long. The old roadway continues a bit until reaching the western access near US 30. The trail is entirely on old turnpike roadbed. The pavement is broken in spots, but easily traveled. Inside the tunnels can be extremely dark and damp. Watch for broken concrete, drips from overhead, and trash (including glass) in the tunnels.

hits.name: Hartwood Acres
hits.description:
Users have recommended bringing the app or downloaded map because it can be hard to follow the route with so many trails in the area.

Hartwood Acres is a beautiful park acquired by Allegheny county from the Lawrence family in 1969.  Situated on this 629 acres park are the original mansion, stables, and support structures used by the family.  The park also offers nearly a dozen miles of hiking trails.  In addition to hiking, the park amenities include summer concerts, mansion tours, teas, an off-leash dog area, and cross-country skiing, walking, and bridle trails.  For more information on the park, please visit https://www.alleghenycounty.us/parks/hartwood/index.aspx

hits.name: Pine Creek Trail
hits.description: A rail trail that goes from Jersey Shore PA to Wellsboro PA. It . follows the old railraod grade that snaked up Pine Creek. The trail also goes through the Pennsylvania Grand Canyon.

hits.name: Balanced Rock Viewing Area
hits.description:
Nice short hike with gorgeous scenes, foliage, and overlooks - great for the whole family.

This trail is not considered wheelchair or stroller friendly because some of the bridges have a couple of stair steps or a lip greater than 2 inches, there are areas where the cross slope is greater than 2%, and there are some large rocks breaking up the surface. However, with assistance, some equipment users may be able to do this trail. The trail surface is dirt and it is typically at least three feet wide.

hits.name: Bear Creek Red and Gray Loop
Laurel Highlands Trail
hits.description: This 70-mile footpath extends from the Youghiogheny River Gorge at Ohiopyle State Park east of Uniontown, Pennsylvania, to the one thousand foot-deep Conemaugh Gorge near Johnstown. There are eight overnight areas, each with five shelters, tent pads, bathrooms and potable water. Camping is permitted only at these areas, which are located eight to ten miles apart. The terrain is generally moderate, and a number of road crossings provide ample opportunities for both out-and-back and one-directional day-hiking. Markers at all mile-points takes the guesswork out of gauging distance traveled.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Caledonia Park to Old Forge Road
hits.description:
White-blazed trail is generally easy walking, with occasional traversing of rock outcroppings and small boulder fields.  Views are generally hemmed in by trees, but two scenic vista are marked by signs on trail, one north of 233 allows view of South Mountain Restoration Center, and the more spectacular Chimney Rocks vista is close to the southern carpark. One tricky area in the trail is a jog on Coral Ridge Road.  Be sure to follow the white blazes; there are several false trails leaving the road.

Hiking south to north gets the vertical change out of the way, leaving a predominantly gentle downhill the rest of the way. Many come from the north, leaving a moderately steep descent at the southern end. For those who only wish to climb to Chimney Rocks from the south and go back down, there is a blue-blazed alternative trail (an old logging road) at the Chimney Rock turnoff which rejoins the Appalachian Trail at Tumbling Run Creek.

Antietam Shelter is not open for camping, but there is space to set up tents plus frost free water faucet, toilets and pavilions at Old Forge Picnic Grounds.

hits.name: Stone Cutter Trail
hits.description:
This trail includes many little “waterfalls” on the way that you can see only from down below but also some awesome rock fixtures along the trail. Once you get to the top, you will walk past the gate and follow the trail on the the right. 

At the beginning of the trail you will follow blue and orange markers until you get to the top which then you start to follow yellow markers until you eventually get back to blue and orange ones again. 

Going down the steep incline for the last mile is technical and can be  slippery because of the leaves and loose rocks. If you don’t want to go the entire loop but still want to see the beautiful views you can travel counter clock wise up the trail.

hits.name: Wissahickon Lavender, Orange, and Yellow Trail Loop
The Spirit Of Tuscarora Trail
hits.description:
This route can be accessed by either the trailhead shown on this page, or by starting on Church Street and looping around the lake, before reaching the starting point shown here.

This route starts as yellow blazed, and then white, then red.

hits.name: Bears Rocks via Appalachian Trail (Bake Oven Road)
ChesLen Yellow Loop
hits.description: The park is closed to visitors on Thursday weekly.

hits.name: Perkiomen Trail: Perkiomenvile to Spring Mount
Governor Dick Blue and White Diamond Loop
hits.area_name: Clarence Schock Park at Governor Dick
hits.description: This trail starts out on Red Rectangle Trail (2), Fire Road (1) , Blue Diamond (12), makes a curve to the right at Yellow Circle (14), and finishes off with White Diamond (15).

hits.name: Harrisburg Capital Area Greenbelt Trail
hits.description: The trail is a loop through and around Harrisburg. It passes along the Susquehanna River through Riverfront Park, through wooded areas, urban areas, residential areas, and scenic parks, including Reservoir Park and Wildwood Park. Parts of the trail share the road, but most of the loop is on dedicated paths. Most of the trail is paved but portions are gravel or crushed stone. There is plenty of parking at various locations along the route, which is marked with signs every mile.

hits.name: Laurel Highlands Hiking Trail: Ohiopyle to Myersbrook
Alpha Pass Trail
hits.description: Alpha Pass: blue blazes. This trail is at the northern end of McConnells Mill State Park and is part of the North Country National Scenic Trail. This trail begins at the Alpha Pass scenic vista and follows the east bank of Slippery Rock Creek. There is an exit to the Point Parking Area or the trail follows the creek to the Old Mill.

hits.name: Boyd Big Tree Preserve Conservation Area Creek Trail
hits.area_name: Boyd Big Tree Preserve Conservation Area
hits.description: This is one of the more difficult trails in the Boyd big tree area. It starts off on a slight decent on a wide gravel path, then makes a hard left to continue down to the creek where it becomes increasingly narrow. On the way down to the creek there are stone steps. The trail crosses the creek by means of a small "stone bridge". Once across the creek the trail starts to gain elevation while becoming increasingly rocky and full of large roots from the surrounding trees. Eventually the trail comes to a split. To the left the trail takes a steeper ascent  and to the right it is more gradual. After completing the loop the trail joins back up with the first section where it follows the creek again. This trail is marked with blue blazes.

hits.name: Warwick to Ephrata Rail Trail: Ephrata
hits.description:
This path is heavily trafficked throughout Ephrata, and also close to Warwick.  Other portions of the path are almost empty. 

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Railroad Avenue at the east end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 5 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for a moderately steep (5-8%) downhill section at about 1.1 miles when going westbound. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Alpine Street to Uplands to Mountain Top Loop
Pulpit Rock, Red Trail, and Furnace Creek Trail Loop
Appalachian Trail to Cumberland Valley Overlook
La Ho Trail
hits.description: This single-track dirt trail is a very pleasant trail to hike. This has lovely water and land views with multiple small bridges and some slight inclines.

hits.name: Birdsboro Quarry and Trap Rock
hits.description:
Birdsboro quarry is a neat little place to climb if you like short sport routes. The approach is an easy ten minute walk from your car. If you start on the Haycreek Road side you'll have to cross a creek. 

It's a popular area with a fairly extensive history. On any day with nice weather you will usually find a few parties using the area along with hikers. The difficulties range through the whole spectrum from easy to very hard making it a place where beginners and experts alike can find a challenge. The rock quality varies from place to place and helmets are recommended.

hits.name: Mitchell Trail, Creek Road and Raytharn Trail Loop
Mount Misery Trail, Wolfinger Trail, and Valley Creek Trail
hits.description: Great walk in this historic National Park. Easy. Heavy traffic on weekends. Perfect for a nice walk in the park. Very informative and serene trail. Good for people who like history.

hits.name: Ridley Yellow Trail to White Trail Loop
Pinchot Lake Loop
hits.description: Many parts of the trail are easy walking with gravel surfaces, but some of the remote sections are narrow with uneven footing. Many hikers combine portions of this trail with other trails like Alpine, Gravel, Oak and Quaker Race to make shorter loops.

hits.name: Witch's Hat via Upper Glen Trail
hits.description:
Please consult the park's website before visiting here: https://visitpaamericana.com/partner/west-reading-neversink-mountain-loop/

Somewhat challenging but very doable hike and an easy ride. It can be done clockwise or counterclockwise, this is a nice little workout. You have nice views of both sides of the mountain by taking the Cove Trail up to the Southern Outlook!

hits.name: Kurmes Paradise Creek Nature Preserve from Devils Hole Road
North Park White Trail
hits.description: Short loop in the southern section of North Park.  Park at Pie Traynor Baseball Field and find the start of the white loop past the soccer field.

hits.name: White Pine, College Park, Number One Lane and Mill Dairy Trail
hits.description: Fairly easy route with a mixture of paved paths and off road trails.

hits.name: Iris Trail to Lake Rutherford via Appalachian Trail
Opossum Lake Trail
hits.description: for more info on what is happening at Opossum Lake and how to help visit: https://www.opossumlakefriends.org/

hits.name: Perkiomen Trail and Audubon Loop Trail
Lehigh River Gorge: Jim Thorpe to Penn Haven Junction
Wissahickon Orange and Forbidden Drive Trail Loop
hits.description:
Park at south trailhead along Lincoln Drive and start on easy the Forbidden Trail, cross over to Orange for a little adventure. Some elevation, mud, rocks, and roots. 

Pretty views that with make you forget that you are in Philadelphia!  Cross Fingerspan Bridge, pass Devils Pool then cross over to Forbidden Drive at Valley Green Dive. 

Enjoy drinks and food at Valley Green Inn! Yummy and great service! 

Return to start location by going back following Forbidden Drive for an easier walk.

hits.name: McCune Trail
hits.description: This is a fun hike in the woods. There is a beautiful overlook at one point with a bench to sit and relax. Beautiful view about 1.5 miles in and some nice rocky formations.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Boiling Springs to Rt 850
hits.description: A moderately easy 16 mile hike on the AT.  It can easily be done as an overnighter. Most of the journey is through corn fields and cow pastures while the last portion takes you through the woods.

hits.name: Lake Border Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Blue Marsh Lake National Recreation Area
hits.description: Dogs are welcome to be off leash on multi-use trails, bust must be on leash in developed areas and are not permitted on beaches, picnic areas, or boat beaches.

hits.name: York Heritage Trail along Codorus Creek
hits.description: Northern Extension of the York County Heritage Rail Trail

hits.name: Trail 5, The Gut, Rusty Chair, Trail 7 Loop
Ricketts Evergreen Trail
hits.description: This trail is rated in the "Easiest" category by the park and it is not marked with blazes. You can view Adams Falls along the trail and groves of very old evergreens.

hits.name: Pinchot Trail - North
hits.description:
Please be mindful and considerate when hiking this trail as it is easy to end up near or on private property.  

Vista with observation deck, rhododendron forest, varied ecosystems and terrain.

With numerous side trails, the possibilities for exploring the  23+ miles of Lackawanna State Forest's Pinchot Trail system are plentiful. There are several wet spots, as well a few rocky areas, so bring proper footwear. Also, a few of the trails pass near, and occasionally through, private land. Please respect the rights of local landowners, and stay on the marked trails. The lookout tower on top of Big Pine Hill is accessible by road, so expect to have company, especially during the weekend.  

A sign at the trailhead says that the Pinchot Trail is blazed blue, when in fact most of the blue blazes have been painted over in ORANGE.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Whisky Spring to Rocky Ridge
Cheslen Preserve via Embreeville Road
hits.description: The 1,263-acre ChesLen Preserve is one of the largest private nature preserves in southeastern Pennsylvania and features sweeping agricultural fields, densely wooded stream corridors, and rare serpentine barrens. There are many points on the property from which visitors can gaze for miles in any direction and see virtually no signs of modern development. In 2010, The Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (PA DCNR) designated portions of ChesLen Preserve, specifically the Unionville Barrensas, a Pennsylvania Wild Plant Sanctuary. The program encourages the conservation of natural areas and native plants, and recognizes private landowners who serve as models of good conservation and stewardship of these special resources.

hits.name: Longwood Gardens
hits.description: Very flat. An easy trail. Walk the gardens as well they are beautiful.

hits.name: Idlewood Trail
hits.description: These trails are carved in to a hillside running down to Neshaminy Creek.  It has some great downhill runs, some really rocky, steep uphill climbs, and is in fairly good condition year round.

hits.name: Swatara State Park South Loop
hits.description:
A picturesque trail that’s very easy to navigate with gentle sloping at times, but nothing overly strenuous. You can see an old canal lock along the way. Great ride on a bicycle.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the partially paved parking lot off of Suedberg Road at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The restrooms at this parking lot are designated wheelchair accessible. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at bridges) or packed gravel, and typically at least 5 feet wide. There are bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.1, 0.6, 1.9 through 2.1, 2.8 through 3.7, 4.2, 4.6, and 5.9 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Blue Mountain Ridge to Port Clinton
hits.description:
This is a nice section of trail that can be done as either a day hike, or an overnighter.

This section of trail starts in the town of Port Clinton and runs along the top of the ridge to Rt 183.  It is possible to hike this section in a day.  Alternatively, it could be done as overnighter.  Eagles Nest Shelter sleeps 8 and is located around the halfway point.

hits.name: Charcoal Trail to D&L Trail Loop
Charcoal Hearth to Thaddeus Stevens Trail
Wissahickon Yellow Loop via Hermit Lane
Jonathan Eshenour Memorial Trail
hits.description:
Bikes are NOT allowed on the nature trail but are allowed on the other ones.

This is a mostly paved trail with gradual inclines and declines. Bikes and pets welcome. There are connections to Shank Park, Bullfrog Valley Pond and other major communities in Hershey. There are several road crossings necessary to fully navigate the trail, so please use caution.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Bullfrog Valley Road at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or a natural surface (dirt, grass, roots). It is typically at least 6 feet wide. There are metal bollards at street crossings which reduces the width temporarily. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the paved portion in the first about 1.8 miles when going counterclockwise. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 2.0, 2.2-2.3, 2.7, and 3.0-3.2 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade between 1.8-3.3 miles when going counterclockwise.

hits.name: Westmoreland Heritage Trail: Trafford to West Export
Jackson Falls and Rock Furnace Trail
hits.description: The waterfalls are off trail and cross onto private property, please stay on the trail to ensure continued access.

hits.name: Castenea Boulder Field Loop
hits.description: An offline map is recommended to get oriented as users have reported that the trail is not marked well.

hits.name: Neal Thorpe Loop
hits.description:
This loop which encompasses the Neal Thorpe Trail and a portion of the Schuylkill River Trail (SRT) features gorges, creeks, overlooks, trickling water cascades, and more in this 2 mile loop trail conveniently adjacent to Phoenixville's Lock 60 Park and Schuylkill Canal Park. 

The Neal Thorpe trail is the namesake of a Mont Clare woman born in 1920 who worked to establish the Schuylkill Canal Association to restore and protect the  canal and its associated property after they had fallen into disrepair. Thanks to the hard work of Neal Thorpe (1920-2018) and others, the 200-year-old canal and it's historical properties can be enjoyed by thousands of visitors annually.

hits.name: Lamb's Gap Trail
hits.description: Mountain biking is not permitted.

hits.name: Laurel Highland Hiking Trail: Rt. 653 to Grindle Ridge
hits.description:
Fairly level trek along ridge w/ several overlooks and rock mazes. (5 miles)

The yellow-blazed Laurel Highland Hiking Trail covers 70 miles from Ohiopyle State Park north to Seward. This review covers the 5.2 mile section between PA Route 653 and the Grindle Ridge Shelter Area.

The two most interesting features of this section of the trail are the rocky overlooks of Middle Fork and a Rock Maze. The broken geology is damage done during the last Ice Age when this section of Pennsylvania was tundra and subjected to freeze-thaw cycles that 12,000 year later make the trail rocky and tough on the feet. 

The trail designers take some delight in the terrain by running the trail through these huge cracks in the stone rather than taking the easier route around them.When the trail is hot, these rocky corridors can be significantly cooler although they also harbor colonies of mosquitos.

The cross trail's marked with orange disks are for cross-country skiing. The consession at the 653 parking area is open during the weekends during the winter.

hits.name: Wintergreen Gorge Trail
hits.description: Users report that the Penn State Behrend Parking lot is often open when the main parking lot may be closed due to extreme weather, since it is unmaintained.

hits.name: Delaware Canal: New Hope to Washington Crossing
hits.description:
Smooth even trail with historic significance. (6 miles)

This section of the Delaware Canal is much like the entirety of the towpath in that it has a smooth and even surface of crushed red stone. The highlight is Washington Crossing Historic Park which is broken into two sections. The Northern section has picnic pavilions on the river side and a monument to unknown soldiers who died of exposure while Washington's Army camped before Christmas of 1776.This also has the Bowman's Hill Wildflower Preserve. The Southern section of the park containes the site where the crossing actually took place as well as picnic pavillions.

Crossing here, riding the D&R Canal North to Lambertville and back to the Parking lot is a 15 mile loop

hits.name: Greenwood Furnace State Park Loop
hits.description: The trailhead is right across the street from the visitor center.

hits.name: Montour Trail
hits.description:
This is a pleasant mostly paved multi-use rail-trail (currently a total of 46 miles long but connects to other trails as well) with tunnels and bridges and some moderate hills.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Brownsville Road at the southeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. There are metal bollards at street crossings which reduces the width. 

The mostly accessible portion of the trail is the last about 3.2 miles from 33.5-33.7 miles. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 1.0-1.1, 7.9-8.1, 11.5-11.6, and 19.1-19.3 when going northwest. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. 

There are benches along the route for resting. The most accessible portion of the trail is the Montour Trail-Coraopolis to Beaver Grade:  https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/pennsylvania/montour-trail-coraopolis-to-beaver-grade

hits.name: The Willows and Skunk Hollow Loop
hits.description: The Willows Park and Skunk Hollow is a great little spot on the DelCo ChesCo line. This is a pretty areas along the creeks. The trails are all navigable and easy to find.

hits.name: Lincoln Drive Trail
hits.description:
This trail starts off of Lincoln Drive where the Wissahickon and Monoshone Creeks meet. The trail then heads south, paralleling the Wissahickon and Lincoln Drive to meet the Schuylkill River.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Lincoln Drive at the northeast end of the trail. At least two of the spots have striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at bridges), and typically at least 5 feet wide. There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Cold Run Extension Trail
hits.description:
Cold Run Trail is a 1.5 mile extension of the Canyon Vista Trail. Access to the Cold Run Trail is from the new Canyon Vista Trailhead on PA 154, east of the park’s campground. Follow the Canyon Vista Trail clockwise .7 of a mile climbing the mountain to the signed lower trailhead of the Cold Run Trail. The blazes of Cold Run Trail are yellow.

The Cold Run Trail continues the climb easing off as it merges with an old lumber road. The road gently weaves through the forest leading the trail to the Cold Run Vista. The view is eastward looking up the Loyalsock Creek valley and PA 154. 

The trail enters a downhill “serpentine” after which it begins its ascent of the Cold Run watershed. Sacagawea and Tendoy waterfalls, as well as a few smaller ones, are viewed as the trail parallels the stream. The trail crosses the west branch of Cold Run just below Tecumseh Falls. Continuing to climb the trail passes Aliquippa Falls just before it crosses the main branch of Cold Run. The trail once again passes Aliquippa Falls before ascending Aliquippa Rock which offers a view of Cold Run Falls. 

 Leaving the rock the trail climbs, crosses the east branch of Cold Run, then levels off at .9 of a mile in a hemlock grove. The trail reaches the main branch of Cold Run, follows it downstream, crosses the stream, then arrives at Cold Run Falls.

The trail turns away from the falls into a beech forest. Shortly the trail begins a descent of the west branch of Cold Run along various small cascades. The trail crosses the stream, twists through some rocks, follows a skid road before joining a wider lumber road.

After the road levels out the trail veers left, passes Flynn Spring, then begins a climb up the hillside to an escarpment. The trail ventures through the rocks, through crevasses and even under Boulder Arch, a truck size slanted rock. The climb continues until leveling off in a young beech forest. The hike is gentle through the woods until it descends the escarpment then hugs the base of the rock. Another crevasse is encountered utilizing a few rock steps to enter the chasm. After the passage the trail suddenly arrives in a large “room” of ferns surrounded by separate sections of the escarpment. The trail abruptly ends at its upper trailhead intersection with the Canyon Vista Trail.

The waterfalls on Cold Run Trail are best viewed during snow melt in the spring or within a few days after a significant rainfall. As with any trail in the winter, ice cleats are strongly recommended. Due to the areas fragile ecology please stay on the trail. Please respect the solitude and be mindful of other hikers.

hits.name: Old Field and Jennings Trail Loop
Blue Mountain Ski Area via Appalachian Trail
Pine Grove Furnace to Toms Run
hits.description:
Nice little out and back hike along a portion of the AT

This out and back hike heads uphill at the beginning past several cabins.  It's easy to follow the white blazes.  There are some flat rocks after a mile or so where you can sit and enjoy a snack and some water.

The turnaround point is at the bridge crossing Tom's Run.  The stream is nice and is a great place to soak your feet if you're hiking during the summer.

Just before you reach the stream you'll see another trail (blue blazes) going off to the left.  That will take you to the Sunset Rocks Overlook at the top of the ridge.

hits.name: Devil's Hole Trail
hits.description: You may want to bring waterproof shoes as there are creek crossings along the way. The mapped route ends where private property begins - please turn around at that point.

hits.name: Dales Ridge Trail
hits.description: Hikers have reported this trail can be icy in the winter months, please use caution when hiking.

hits.name: Youghiogheny River Trail - Ohiopyle to Confluence
hits.description:
Beautiful rapids nearby. (11 miles)

The beauty of the Southern Ohiopyle section of the trail rivals that of the Northern section. Rapids abound and there are plenty of places to leave the trail and find your way down to the rivers edge. 

Approaching Confluence is a place known as Turkeyfoot, the confluence of Laurel Hill Creek, the Youghiogheny and Cassleman Rivers. George Washington slept here in 1754 and there is a plaque here telling you all about it.

Confluence is also the connecting point to the Allegheny Highlands Trail which continues 30 miles to Meyersdale and will eventually extend to Cumberland, Md and the C&O Canal Towpath.

The TOPO! Overlay file included with this review contains data for the entire 70 miles of the Youghiogheny River Trail from McKeesport to Confluence.

hits.name: Clark Run Rager Mountain Trail Loop
Sawmill Lake To Monument High Point
hits.description:
This is an awesome trail that can get a little difficult at times, depending on the trail conditions. Be prepared for a steep incline in the beginning, climbing over rocks, and a lot of elevation change. 

Parking is available at Sawmill Lake, on the road off Route 406. There is a parking lot there for about 12 cars and a very nice camping site too.

hits.name: Farview, Appalachian, Blue Dot, Fire Road, Turquoise, and Dunnfield Creek Trails Loop
hits.description: This is a nice challenging loop that goes mainly through wooded areas but also follows a stream at some points. Near Sunfish Pond is especially steep and rocky, but it has beautiful views. Swimming is not allowed there.

hits.name: Raccoon Ridge via Douglas and Garvey Springs Trails Loop
hits.description: This route can also be done as an out-and-back by just using the Garvey Springs Trail and then returning on it. It is rockiest by Sunfish Pond. Swimming is not allowed there. The Douglas Trail has dark blue blazes and the Garvey Springs Trail has orange blazes.

hits.name: Eliza Furnace Trail
hits.description:
This paved trail parallels the Monongahela River and Interstate-376, and is part of the Three Rivers Heritage Trail in Pittsburgh. This section leads from the southwest corner of Schenley Park to Point State Park and the Downtown section of the TRHT and back.

Since the trail runs along the Monongahela River, it offers views of many iconic Pittsburgh sites: South Side, the Hot Metal Bridge, Liberty Bridge, the Smithfield Street Bridge, and Mount Washington can all be seen from the trail. Wildflowers, when in season, also line the trail, allowing for a very scenic experience.  

Accessibility: There are 10 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Swinburne Street at the east end of the trail. 3 of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete (with railings at bridges), smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Moraine and Glacier Loop
hits.description:
When the parking area is gated, you can also park at the end of Alexander Road. Please be cautious, as there is seasonal hunting in the area. Bringing the app or downloading the offline map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that the trail is not marked clearly.

This is a great work out. It continually climbs up and down with switchbacks. It gets more rocky at the end.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: PA 309 to Lehigh Gap
hits.description:
This challenging section of trail will require you to navigate over and around car sized boulders.

This section of trail runs along the top of the ridge.  There are plenty of fantastic views, two shelters, and multiple campsites that aren't listed on the map.  You'll also get to hike over the Lehigh Tunnel, but it's hard to know when you're actually over it.  

This is a rugged section of trail with a lot of boulders to navigate over.

hits.name: Governor Dick Firetower via Horseshoe Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Clarence Schock Park at Governor Dick

hits.name: Schuylkill River Trail: Hamburg to Auburn
hits.description: This is one of the northernmost sections of the Schuylkill River Trail as of 2020--there is a plan to connect the sections of the trail from Frackville to Philadelphia. The path is crushed stone, which is perfect for running, walking, biking, and strollers. The path is nice and shady, perfect for getting out there on a humid summer day! Read more on the official Schuylkill River Greenways website: https://schuylkillriver.org/schuylkill-river-trail/

hits.name: Grand View and Old Beaver Dam Loops via Falls Trail
hits.description: Falls Trail plus Old Beaver Dam Trail to Grand View and Ganoga View. The Falls Trail is always great and there are so many waterfalls - this route adds two more loops that take you through some nice forest and then to the Fire Tower at the highest peak at Ricketts. Grand View and Old Beaver Dam are both marked with yellow blazes. Grand View is considered "Easiest" and Old Beaver Dam is considered "More Difficult" by the park website.

hits.name: Auburn Lookout via the Appalachian Trail
Pinchot Trail
hits.description: The Pinchot Trail is a loop that is normally traveled counter-clockwise and can be separated into a Northern Loop and a Southern Loop. The trail is marked by orange blazes and side trails marked by yellow blazes. The Northern Loop is mainly flat and rocky whereas the Southern Loop has multiple elevation changes. The primary water source for the Northern Loop is Painter's Creek. The primary water source for the Southern Loop is Choke Creek. The Northern Loop has campsites early into the trail that makes overnight trips very easy to do.

hits.name: Seneca Viewpoint and Fire Tower Trail
Pennell Falls, Peter's Corner Loop
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Schuylkill River Trail: Betzwood to Port Providence
WPP Red And Blue Trail Loop
The Throne Room, Standing Stone Trail
Horsham Powerline Trail
hits.description: This trail has some grade, but there are segments that are WHEELCHAIR accessible.

hits.name: Binky Lee Preserve Trail
hits.area_name: Natural Lands' Trust Binkey Lee Preserve

hits.name: Bear Creek Preserve Waterfall via Purple Trail
Main Trail, River Lookout and Chimney Rock
Boulevard Trail to Watershed Trail Loop
Toms Run Nature Reserve
hits.description: Beautiful diverse woodland and wetland. Trail is well marked.

hits.name: High Point via Appalachian Trail
hits.description: A more rewarding Way to 'Summit' the High Point of NJ than driving. This is the westerly route up the eastern slope of the ridge. You will ascend around 900 feet in elevation to the summit. Also, close to the top, there is a wooden observation deck.

hits.name: Mt Nittany: White Trail to Mike Lynch Overlook
hits.description: If you want to hike up Mount Nittany but don't have time to do the full loop, this short hike will take you up the mountain to the most iconic view. Beginning from the parking lot, the climb begins immediately. You will soon meet a junction with the blue trail going to the left. Continue straight on the white trail. After about half a mile of climbing you will reach the top where there is another junction. Take a right here, towards the Mike Lynch overlook. After about .1 mile you will reach this overlook, where there are beautiful views of State College and Penn State. After taking it all in, retrace your steps back down the mountain.

hits.name: Wissahickon Valley Orange, Yellow and Kitchen’s Bridge Loop
hits.description: Orange trail is rocky with up/down vertical on NE side of Creek. Yellow trail on SW side is smoother and follows the ridge line - good for mountain bikes and horses.

hits.name: Lake Williams and Lake Redman
hits.description: Lovely in all seasons, not too trafficked as to be annoying but there's almost always someone out there.   Pretty views of the lakes, a little highway noise but not too intrusive.

hits.name: Stroud Preserve Yellow and Red Loop
hits.description:
The Stroud Preserve consists of 571 acres of culturally and ecologically important land in Chester County. This rolling mosaic of once-pastured grasslands, working farmlands, and woodlands now serves as wildlife habitat and a unique site for research by the Stroud Water Research Center. The preserve is closed on Wednesday weekly.

The Stroud Preserve features nearly 9.5 miles of unpaved trails ranging from easy to moderate.  One such trail is the Yellow Trail, which is a 2.4 mile loop trail rated as easy.  The trail skirts farm fields and forests; occasional dipping into the treeline.  The trail is open to horseback riding and has a few mucky spots where the horses have pounded the dirt into mud (depending on season and recent weather).

hits.name: Pretzel Hut through Rannels Kettle via Horse-shoe Trail
hits.description: Strenuous trail with several climbs. Begins at Pretzel Hut on 501, climbs to Eagle Rock overlook, then descends to 322. Cross 322 to climb Rannels Kettle, loop around and cross back over 322. Take the blue trail up through another rocky climb, then back past Eagle Rock to 501.

hits.name: Beaver Trail and Yellow Ridge Trail
Antietam Lake to Mount Penn Loop via Ferndale and Gravity Trails
Tom's Creek Trail
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Creek Trail, Lower Trail and Monocacy Hill Trail
Wissahickon Orange Trail, Lavender Trail and Forbidden Drive
Ringing Rocks via Delaware Canal
hits.description: Parking for the trail is on the opposite side of the street. Parking on the south side of the road is private property, please use the lot on the north side of the road and cross the street to begin the hike.

hits.name: Water Tank and Rattling Run Trail Loop via Appalachian Trail
Pinchot Trail: South Loop
hits.description: Walks along Choke Creek, with six or seven different campsites, some with pretty creek views. Very popular in the summer.

hits.name: Pequea Creek Nature Trail (Conestoga Trail Segment)
Settler's Cabin Red Trail to Lake Loop
ChesLen Preserve Loop Trail
hits.description: The 1,263-acre ChesLen Preserve—one of the largest private nature preserves in southeastern Pennsylvania—features sweeping agricultural fields, densely wooded stream corridors, and rare serpentine barrens. There are many points on the property from which visitors can gaze for miles in any direction and see virtually no signs of modern development. In 2010, The Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (PA DCNR) designated portions of ChesLen Preserve—specifically the Unionville Barrens—as a “Pennsylvania Wild Plant Sanctuary.” The program encourages the conservation of natural areas and native plants, and recognizes private landowners who serve as models of good conservation and stewardship of these special resources. At the top of the loop, crossing Embreeville Road will lead you to the Stargazer's Stone at the bottom of Stargazers Road. This stone was placed by Mason and Dixon as a critical navigation point for plotting the famous line.

hits.name: Youghiogheny River to Jonathan Run Falls
hits.description:
Hike along the Youghiogheny River Trail from Ohiopyle to the famous Dimple Rock, the most difficult rapid on the Lower Yough.

The trail is quite easy up to the waypoint "ds". There is a small marker on the trail indicating the path down to the river. Near that is a larger sign warning against unauthorized swimming in the rapids.

Be careful on the steps, as many of them are rotted out.

Once you reach the river, there are a number of rocks along the shoreline. Hike upstream for a short distance to reach Dimple Rock. When it is wet the rocks are quite slippery, so be careful.

The best times to do this are during rafting hours on Saturday and Sunday, between 9am and 2pm, during summer and early fall months.

Pull up a spot on the rock and enjoy the show of rafters navigating the rapids!

Check the height of the river before doing this hike. If the river is high, there will be no rafts to watch, and the river will be flowing over the lower rocks, making it dangerous or impossible to reach Dimple.

hits.name: Wissahickon Lavender and White Trails
hits.description: This trail is high along the river, with views of the covered bridge and many options for alternate routes.

hits.name: Buttermilk Falls Trail
hits.description: The area where Fred Rogers (Mr. Rogers) spent time growing up and enjoying the natural beauty this area has to offer on his parents property.

hits.name: Quehanna Trail
hits.description: The Quehanna Trail passes through the Moshannon and Elk State Forests which offer some of the most wild and beautiful country in Pennsylvania.

hits.name: Duff Park Outer Loop
hits.description: This trail is well marked and is a moderate to difficult terrain.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Boiling Springs to White Rock Trail
hits.description: Hiked from parking lot behind lake up to and past the Center Point Knob marker and returned on the same trail.  Moderate trail.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: South Mountain Ridge through Pine Grove Furnace State Park
Appalachian Trail: Old Forge Picnic Grounds to Caledonia State Park
Governor Dick Tower Trail
hits.area_name: Clarence Schock Park at Governor Dick

hits.name: Great Gorge to Meadow Branch Trail
Green Lane Reservoir Park Red Trail
Swatara Rail Trail
hits.description:
This is a peaceful paved and gravel rail-trail that goes across bridges and by a historic cabin and a nice waterfall.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Swopes Valley Road at the northeast end of the trail. The trail surface is paved asphalt (old road with cracks or grass), packed gravel, or wooden bridges with railings and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less), except for moderately steep (5-8%) and steep (8-12%) sections at about 4.1 miles uphill, 4.5 miles downhill, and 5.4 miles when going southwest. Trail goers using wheelchair/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: East Shore Trail, Eagle Pass, and Cliff Trail
D&L Trail: Yardley to Washington Crossing
Laurel Highlands Hiking Trail Mile 70 to 0
hits.description:
This route covers the entire Laurel Highlands Hiking Trail (LHHT) heading southbound from mile 70 in Seward, PA to mile 0 in Ohiopyle. The route was completed in 5 days and 4 nights, but can be adapted to suit your needs and reversed as well. There are mile markers along the entire trail and yellow blazes every 50 feet or so. The extension trails to the campsites are marked with blue blazes and there is a sign post displaying "Shelter Area" at each junction. 

The terrain can be challenging at times with the most difficult sections at the beginning and end of the trail. There are some amazing views along the way and if you time it right, you can stop by Seven Springs on your way through to get cleaned up and grab a soda. 

Camping is restricted to certain locations and there is a small fee per person, per night. The following campsite locations can be used. Day 1 - RT 271, Day 2 - Turnpike, Day 3 - Grindle Ridge, Day 4 - Bidwell. For more information, please visit https://www.dcnr.pa.gov/Recreation/WhatToDo/Hiking/LaurelHighlandsHikingTrail/Pages/default.aspx.

hits.name: Lake Border Trail - North Loop
hits.area_name: Blue Marsh Lake National Recreation Area

hits.name: Indian Steps to Tussey Fire Tower Ruins
Hawk and Pinnacle Mountains via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
You cannot park overnight at the starting point on this map route. Thru-hikes are only allowed overnight camping and you must be dropped off then picked up.

This route follows the Appalachian and Skyline to visit Hawk Mountain looping back down to the Appalachian, Pinnacle, Valley Rim and Red Trail to make another loop taking you to Pinnacle Mountain.

hits.name: Lenape Trail to Mill Creek Trail Loop
Horseshoe Trail: Furnace Hills Pike to Horseshoe Trail Road
Governor Dick Hill
hits.area_name: Clarence Schock Park at Governor Dick
hits.description: This hike starts at the environmental center and ends at Governor Dick Tower.

hits.name: Panhandle Trail-Walkers Mill To Gregg Station
Bear Creek Red Loop Trail
hits.description: Woodland hike through rocky terrain with several primitive creek crossings.

hits.name: Butler-Freeport Trail
hits.description: There are several different access points to this route. Considering this is a point-to-point trail, you can make the distance whatever you want by just turning around and returning to your car from any of the access points.

hits.name: Steel Valley Trail - The Waterfront
hits.description:
What was once the vast Homestead Steelworks has been reborn as the Waterfront, a huge collection of retail, corporate offices, restaurants, and luxury townhouses. Gas lights illuminate the trail after dark and you will go by numerous restaurant patios and townhouse back porches. There is plenty of pedestrian traffic along this section of the trail.

Utilizing seldom trafficked concrete sidewalks at either end, you can extend the trail 2.5 miles. Were it not for Sandcastle Water Park's resistance to having a bike trail go by their property, it would be a short connection west to the South Side section of the Three Rivers Heritage trail and then into Pittsburgh. 

Accessibility: There are at least 20 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of West Waterfront Drive at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along portions of the route for resting.

hits.name: Spring Creek Canyon Trail
hits.description: Nice casual stroll down a wide gravel road next to a wide river. This spot is particularly convenient for a short outing in inclement weather.

hits.name: Wissahickon Orange Trail, Yellow Trail and Lincoln Drive Loop
Hidden Lake Loop
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: High Maintenance Trail via Walker Park
hits.description:
The area around this trail is private property. You MUST begin the trail from Walker Park. All of Woodland Road Extension, including WSC and it’s parking lot, are private property and accessing the trail that way is trespassing and vehicles parked anywhere along the road are in the parking lot may be towed.

Begin the trail from the trailhead at Walker Park on Little Sewickley Creek Road.

hits.name: Delaware Canal: Easton to Durham Furance
hits.description: This is a great trail with nice people. The river is gorgeous, and users report this is great for biking.

hits.name: Mason-Dixon Trail: Hellam Hills
hits.description:
This route is a well-blazed (light blue) and maintained section of Mason-Dixon trail mostly through forest with a minor stream crossing (and mini waterfall). The trail does border along private property as it descends down toward the Susquehanna so be sure to stay on the trail.

The starting point is only a small pull-off area on the road big enough for 2 vehicles, but there is a large parking lot further down River Rd in Accomac if one didn't mind walking on road for a bit to get to the trail (nice views of the river).

hits.name: Hermit's Cave and Lincoln Drive Loop
Ramble Trail
hits.description: Sections of the trail are not well marked, downloading the map ahead of time is helpful.

hits.name: Presque Isle Multi-Purpose Trail From Park Entrance
hits.description:
This is a beautiful paved walking and cycling trail with great views of the water and the fall foliage. There is also beach access and fishing piers. Some of the trail shares the road with vehicles, so using reflective materials, lights, or flagging is recommended for safety. 

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Peninsula Drive at the southeast end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.
