There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. According to the park website, wheelchair-accessible parking spaces, restrooms, picnic tables, and swimming areas are throughout the park. The Environmental Center is also wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: John C. Oliver Multipurpose Loop Trail
hits.description:
This is a lovely paved wooded multi-purpose trail that goes around Lake Wilhelm.

Early in 1954, Pennsylvania Forestry Association president Dr. Maurice K. Goddard wrote a letter to the new administration of Governor George Leader, suggesting things that needed to be done for forestry. Leader was impressed enough to appoint Goddard as his secretary of Forests and Waters. Goddard went on to serve twenty-four years under five governors, establishing the Department of Environmental Resources and building Pennsylvania's State Park System.

The 2,856-acre park that bears his name is dominated by Lake Wilhelm, a popular fishing and boating lake. This trail circuits the lake and, unlike many paved trails, is not flat. There are numerous short hills and dips that can make this a varied but not difficult cycling ride. The north shore section of the trail has a number of bridged stream crossings and more open fields and vistas than the southern shore. The trail on the south shore shares Creek Road for a distance that shares the road with vehicles, so using reflective materials, lights, or flagging is recommended for safety. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Lake Wilhelm Road at the northeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category, but there are steeper sections at about 1.3, 7.8, and 8.1-8.2 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Standing Stone Trail
hits.description: Very rocky, but worth it for some of the best views in central Pennsylvania!

hits.name: Lower Trail to Shingletown Gap Trail
West Rim and Bohen Trail Loop
Appalachian Trail: Peters Mountain to Cove Mountain Shelter to PA 850
hits.description:
This is a nice section of trail.  There are wonderful views of the river as you descend the mountain.  Crossing the Clarks Ferry Bridge over the Susquehanna River and walking through Duncannon was a lot of fun.  The town is very friendly to hikers.  This section also includes the Doyle Hotel, one of the 3 most famous stops on the trail.  

While the hike through town was fun, the hike up the mountain on the other side was not.  It was very rocky, which made for a long slow climb.

hits.name: Presque Isle Multi-Purpose Trail
hits.description:
This is a lovely paved multi-use trail with easy access to beaches for swimming and lots of wildlife. Some of the trail shares the road with vehicles, so using reflective materials, lights, or flagging is recommended for safety. 

Accessibility: There does not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Peninsula Drive at the north end of the trail. However, there is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Peninsula Drive at the southeast end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. This parking lot has been marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. 

There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. According to the park website, wheelchair-accessible parking spaces, restrooms, picnic tables, and swimming areas are throughout the park. The Environmental Center is also wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Boiling Springs to York Road
hits.description: This is a short out-and-back on the famous Appalachian Trail. If you'd like to extend your hike, you can of course continue past York Road going north. You may even choose to make this a point-to-point by leaving a car or getting a ride from another trailhead.

hits.name: Nine Mile Run, Braddock, Kensington, Homewood and Tranquil Loop
Mill Creek Trail
hits.description: Once leaving the trailhead at Shed Road and PA 345, you will not cross another road on this backcountry-type loop trail. Be sure to carry water and wear proper clothing and footwear.

hits.name: Rocky Ridge Trail 5 to Trail 2 to Trail 1 Loop
Eagle Rock and Horse Shoe Trail Loop
Falls Trail to Bear Walk Trail Loop
hits.description: On the Falls Trail you can see many beautiful cascading waterfalls. It is not blazed and is considered to be in the "Most Difficult" category by the park. The Bear Walk Trail is blazed yellow and is in the "Easiest" category. You will need sturdy shoes as there are rocks and roots in the trail. There is a set of stone steps on the trail that can be slippery and wet. It can also be muddy and slippery by the waterfalls.

hits.name: Boyce Park Log Cabin Trail Expanded Loop Trail
The Mocanaqua Loop Trail
hits.description: This trail offers pretty views, but it can be a little difficult to follow, as it is not clearly marked. Offline map is highly recommended!

hits.name: Shawnee Lake Trail
hits.description:
This is a nice loop around the lake that is mostly gravel, with lots of mowing on either side. About 75% of it is in the shade. 

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Lincoln Highway at the north end of the trail. The trail surface is gravel. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade.

hits.name: Rannels Kettle and Horseshoe Trail Loop
Main Trexler Park Loop
hits.description:
This is a paved path with very nice scenery. There are ducks in the pond and it is well-maintained. Bikes are not allowed on some portions of the trail. There are designated cycling and pedestrian lanes, but users have reported that pedestrians don't always stay in their lane, so please use caution. 

Accessibility: There are 7 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Springhouse Road at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 10 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Big Round Top
hits.description:
An offline map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that this trail is not well marked. Please consult the Park's map to orient yourself as signage is very poor in this area. 
https://www.nps.gov/gett/planyourvisit/maps.htm

hits.name: Dark Hollow Woods Trails
hits.description: Nice system of short trails through hilltop woods, gorges, and along Plum Creek.  Penn Hills Community Park can be accessed on the opposite side of Plum Creek.

hits.name: St. Peter's Village The Rocks Trail
hits.description: The Rocks are near an old quarry, which used to operate in St. Peter's Village.  Many Boulders from the quarry were dumped in the creek along with natural boulders, which resulted in a pretty cool place to hike and hop around.  Trails are very poorly marked, and the trail head at the north end of town has no markings or explanation of what lies where.  At the trail-head, there will be three trails to take.  Use the first trail on the left to access the rocks.

hits.name: Peter's Trail
hits.description: The paved part of this loop is only about a 1/4 mile long and the rest of the trail is on a dirt path.

hits.name: Lenape/Mill Creek/Hopewell Furnace
hits.description: Sections of the trail are not well marked, downloading the map ahead of time is recommended.

hits.name: Black Cherry to Butterfly Loop Trail
Stony Mountain Lookout Tower via Rattling Run Trail
Codorus State Park Mountain Bike Area
Yeatman Station Road Loop
hits.description: Nice trail in White Clay Creek State Park that runs largely along both sides of the creek. Beautiful in April when the wildflowers bloom.

hits.name: Vincent DiFilippo Nature Preserve Loop
hits.description: Small, easy loop trail at Vincent DiFilippo Nature Preserve.  Pretty muddy in areas on the crushed gravel path.  There are wetlands, ponds, a creek and towards the back of the park is a bald eagle protected nesting site.

hits.name: Lebanon Reservoir Trail
hits.description: Easy walk or bike ride 2.1 miles to reservoir. Trail is an old railroad bed. Tons of shade cover, in the fall when the leaves are off the tree you can get a great view of the Chinese wall, box car rocks running out the mountain.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail, Hosack Run and Locust Gap Loop
Dam Hill, Dairy Hill, Number One Lane, Nature Trail Loop
hits.description:
Tyler Park has 23.5 miles of interconnected trails some paved and some not. Boat rentals are available seasonally for canoeing on the Neshaminy Creek. There is also a Hostel on the park grounds for overnight stays. Be sure to stop at the park office as you enter the park's main entrance to pick up a park map showing all the trails and recreational opportunities.

Accessibility: This is the most accessible portion of the Tyler State Park Trail https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/pennsylvania/tyler-state-park-trail. There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Main Park Road at the east end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or a natural surface (dirt). It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.6-0.9, 1.6, and 2.4 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type in the unpaved portions. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Cumberland Valley Overlook from Valley Road
Switchback, Abby, Haul, and Van Gorder Trails Loop
hits.description: The elevation change here is minimal making this trail great for beginners and experienced users alike. The trail is well-trodden and easy to follow most of the year, although there are not many blazes. Downloading the map ahead of time is helpful

hits.name: Cold Spot and Hammer Trail Loop
Lake Grubb Loop
hits.description: The park is the site of a former iron ore mine. The ore pit has filled with water, creating Lake Grubb. The park is approximately 54 acres in size. The site is heavily wooded, with a hiking trail encircling the lake. Several fishing areas have been developed. Boating, swimming, and pets are not allowed.

hits.name: Grandon Farms Trail via Creekview Park
Bear Creek Preserve: Green, Gray and Yellow Trails Loop
Katy Jane Trail Loop
hits.description: awesome sunrise from the east view!

hits.name: Dingmans Creek Trail
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
hits.description:
From the Dingmans Falls visitor center, it is a quick walk to Silver Thread Falls along a boardwalk. The boardwalk trail is wide and level which is ideal for those requiring wheelchair access. Silver Thread falls is a tall and thin fall.

The remaining part of the trail to Dingmans Falls is less than a mile and mostly on the boardwalk. Dingmans Falls is impressive in terms of size and flow and has a unique look with its angles drop at the bottom. 

Accessibility: This is the most accessible portion of the longer Dingmans Falls Trail with its own trail page here: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/pennsylvania/dingmans-falls-via-dingmans-creek-trail. That route has stairs, natural, and very steep sections.

There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Dingmans Falls Road at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The visitor center and restrooms are designated accessible by the National Park Service. 

The trail surface is pavement or a wooden boardwalk (with edge barriers and railings) and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Heritage Trail and Camp Trail Loop
Beaver Valley Area Loop
hits.description: A portion of the former route travels through the private property of Beaverbrook Farms. The route shown here has been rerouted to avoid Beaverbrook Farms.

hits.name: Bondsville Mill Park and Nature Trail
Hildacy Farm Preserve Loop
hits.description: The route shown on this page mostly follows the Red Trail around the preserve, with a brief detour around the Purple Trail on the northwestern side of the preserve. At some points the Red Trail shares a trail with the Yellow and Green Trails.

hits.name: Shorb's Summit via Thousand Steps and Standing Stone Trail
McDade Trail
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Allegheny River Trail
hits.description: The trail is made on the remnants of an old rail line and follows the Allegheny River closely.

hits.name: Nature Preserve and Blueberry Loop
hits.area_name: Dick and Nancy Eales Nature Preserve

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Clark Creek to Swatara Gap
Noel Dorwart Park Nature Area Creek Trail
Callahan Run: Black Forest Trail Loop
Trough Creek 5 Sites Loop
hits.description:
This hike will take you through all five of the sites that Trough Creek boasts: Remnants of an old house, Rainbow Falls, Balanced Rock, Ice Mine, and Copperas Rocks. Be sure to see all five.

This is a great hike, a moderate hike with a couple steep climbs and descents, plenty of things to see, streams, wildlife, a few (minor) stream crossings, deciduous and coniferous trees, mountain laurel.

hits.name: Rock Scree and Ridge Overlook Trail
hits.description: This linear trail offers rolling terrain on the way to a pleasant overlook. Benches are strategically placed to relax and enjoy the surrounding view of unbroken forest.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Peters Mountain to Clark's Ferry
Trout Run Trail
hits.area_name: Lancaster Conservancy Trout Run Nature Preserve

hits.name: Palmer-Bethlehem Bikeway
hits.description:
This is a well-maintained paved trail perfect for walking or cycling. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Lehigh Drive at the southeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt with some cracks. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: White Oak Park Trail
hits.description: Nice 810 acre park located in White Oak PA.  Very friendly to mountain bikers.

hits.name: Lebanon Valley Rail Trail: Cornwall To Colebrook
Saucon Rail Trail South
hits.description:
This is a gravel trail that crosses roads a few times, so please use caution. This trail has a slight incline if heading south. It is a nice ride with a mountain bike.  If you want to extend your ride, travel through Upper Saucon Park and pick up the North Saucon Trail near the soccer fields. Traffic can get heavy in the evenings as this is a very popular path for joggers, mobility equipment/strollers, and dog walkers. Keep an eye out for walnuts in the fall - they are everywhere!

Accessibility: There are 6 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Preston Lane at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. There are 8 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of East Pumping Station Road at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt, gravel, or wooden boardwalk with edge barriers. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.3 and 6.0 miles when going south. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Eckville Lot to Blue Mountain House Road
Blue Mountain Ridge via Appalachian Trail
Schuylkill River Trail: Valley Forge to Philadelphia
hits.description:
A popular wooded cycling trail, smoothly paved and wide. There is one gravel section near the 13 mile mark when heading southeast.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lots off of Station Avenue at the northwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is smoothly paved asphalt, wooden boardwalks (with edge barriers and railings), or gravel. It is typically 4 to 8 feet wide with some wider passing spaces. There are painted dividing lines and metal bollards along the trail which reduces the width.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) but there is a steeper section from about 13.0 to 15.0 miles when going southeast. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved section and grade. 

There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms along the trail. The Valley Forge Visitor Center is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Egypt Meadow Lake Loop
hits.description: The north side of the lake between the split has a flooded out section that is easily crossable, but your feet will get wet unless you have waterproof shoes.

hits.name: Wolf Creek Narrows Nature Area
hits.description: There's a fire ring in an open area at a point along the trail and plenty of  trees for hammocking. The trail is well worn but not crowded. Walking alongside the creek is very peaceful. Good for a quick evening walk or a spot to hang out in nature.

hits.name: Tri Valley and Smith Mill Road
hits.description:
This is a magnificent new and fully paved trail. It is great for all levels.

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Sunrise Drive at the northeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section at about 0.7 miles when going south. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety.

hits.name: East Trout Cove and Glacier Ridge Loop
hits.description: Nice loop hike where you walk along the lake for part of it.

hits.name: Abigail, EUB Camp and Dam Breast Access Loop
Neversink Loop via East Ridge Trail
Falls, Wetland, and Gorge Trail Loop
Governor Dick Outer Loop
hits.area_name: Clarence Schock Park at Governor Dick
hits.description:
6 mile loop starting from the Conservation Center. The first part of the hike is easy with more small rocks after the split onto trail #13 & 15. There are no major inclines or declines.

Start by heading to the Horseshoe Trail close to the road. This is marked with yellow blazes. Follow the Horseshoe for little more than 2 3/4 miles then take a right on trail #13 (Dark Green Diamond hash mark). Roughly a mile later take a left onto trail #15 (White Diamond hash mark) and follow the whole way back to the Conservation Center.

hits.name: The Lower Trail
hits.description:
The Lower (pronounce like flower) Trail is a very nice 16+ mile trail in total that runs from Alexandria to near Canoe Creek State Park.  There are a number of trail access points where you can jump on. This trail offers good opportunities for seeing wildlife. Besides hiking and cycling, horseback riding is also permitted.

Accessibility: There does not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of State Route 4014 at the north end of the trail. However, there is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of High Street at about 11.2 miles. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. This parking lot has been marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt, gravel, or a natural surface (grass). It is typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a double track along some of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type.

hits.name: Beartown Rocks Trail
hits.description: Trail head is right off Rt 949. Park off of Corbette Rd.  You can also drive to the rocks, but hiking up the trail makes it more worth it! The trail is on the moderate side of easy and is not extremely well marked.

hits.name: Sunfish Pond via Farview, Appalachian, and Dunnfield Creek Trails Loop
hits.description: Sunfish Pond has beautiful views, but no swimming is allowed. There are multiple creek crossings on the Dunnfield Creek Trail. The trail surface can be rocky and narrow, especially near the pond. You will be following the yellow, white, and light green blazes.

hits.name: Rachel Carson Trail: North Park to Harrison Hills Park
hits.description:
The Rachel Carson Trail is 37 miles of yellow-blazed trail from North Park to Harrison Hills Park. The trail has many access points and can be done in either direction. The route does not have to be done as it is shown on this page. At almost any intersection with a road, the trail is accessible.

There is no camping, so this trail is for day hiking. Power line cuts are popular throughways which means that the trail will often climb straight up or down steep hills.

The annual Rachel Carson Challenge covers the entire 37 miles in one day. Most don't complete the event.

hits.name: Pleasant Valley Park Loop
hits.description: Pleasant Valley Park offers a wide variety of opportunities for hiking. A network of hiking trails have been developed, that allows for hikes of varying lengths and difficulty, by using combinations of trails through woods and existing old farm roads. The park is also crossed by some utility right-of-ways that can also be used for hiking, although they have some very steep areas since they don't follow terrain contours.

hits.name: Big Pocono South and North Trail Loop
hits.description: Trail starts with a gradual downhill on South Trail and then on the way back around the loop has some pretty challenging uphill portions. Overall not an extremely difficult hike, but does have some steep inclines.

hits.name: John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge Loop from Wanamaker Avenue Trailhead
North Country Trail to Jennings Center
hits.description: This is a continuation of the North Country Trail through the northern pan-handle of Moraine State Park. There is a parking lot/trailhead on Route 528 (Prospect Road). The trail runs north mostly along Route 528 and on most of the trail you hear the road traffic. The trail is well marked and maintained. This portion of the North Country Trail leads to the Jennings Environmental Education Center, which is in close proximity to Route 8 and also serves as a trailhead.

hits.name: Montour Trail-Coraopolis to Beaver Grade
hits.description:
This is a crushed limestone rail trail. This section of the Montour Trail is Mile Zero for what will ultimately extend 47 miles Southeast to Clairton. From Montour Road, it travels south past the Forest Grove shooting ranges and the Santucci Conservation Area. 

The profile makes it look more difficult than it really is as, like most rail trails, it is fairly gentle. The trail runs right alongside Montour Run and crosses it three times on bridges. When it's been raining, the run will be muddy, high, and fast. 

The surface is crushed limestone and in only a few places has the fine surface been eroded away to reveal some of the larger grains below. However, there is no roughness of any significance.

Accessibility: This is the most accessible portion of the Montour Trail https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/pennsylvania/montour-trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Montour Coketown at the north end of the trail. However, there are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Old Beaver Grade Road at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. This parking lot has been marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is crushed limestone. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.3 and 2.7 miles when going south. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Old Valley Road East Loop
hits.description: Old, partially abandoned road near Exton Park's northern boundary.  Formerly land owned by Church Farm School, Old Valley Rd. runs from Ship Rd. to Bacton Hill Rd.  Parking is available near the Ship Rd. entrance.  Gates prevent motor vehicles from passing through beyond the remaining residences.

hits.name: Butternut Trail
hits.description: Users recommend doing this hike counter clockwise.

hits.name: South Park White and Red Loop
hits.description: Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

hits.name: Cedar Creek Park: Gorge Trail Loop Trail
Lititz/Warwick Trailway
hits.description:
This is the "Lititz/Warwick" end of the rail trail that connects with the Ephrata Linear Park Trail. This area is mostly farmland mixed with a little bit of woods (more like a tree-lined path) and residential backyards. It is great for running, walking, and cycling. This is a paved path until you get beyond the baseball fields where it turns into loose gravel.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Clay Road at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

hits.name: Shenks Ferry Wildflower Preserve
hits.description: Shenks Ferry Wildflower Preserve is a 85 acre nature preserve along the eastern bank of the Susquehanna River. The trail is approximately 2 miles in length and is renowned for wildflower walks and by naturalists who enjoy seeing spring ephemerals along the ravine and birding. It's an easy walk through the woods back to a tunnel and then turn around and walk out. A stream runs through Shenks Ferry Wildflower Preserve called Grubb Hollow (also referred to as “Grub Run”), which flows southwest  to the Susquehanna River.

hits.name: Conestoga Greenway Trail
hits.description:
This is a wonderful paved and shaded riverside adventure.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of South Duke Street at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, concrete, or stone. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

hits.name: Riverview, Irongate, and Firelane Loop
hits.description: Riverview-Irongate-Firelane Loop: shortly after starting you are scrambling up a hill on a steep shale washout deer trail. Iron Gate makes for a better biking trail with it’s steep embankments put in for mountain bikers, but still hikeable and good for rough trail runners. Some portions of the route are semi paved or graveled, but overall the route is a steep dirt path that is challenging, especially in wet conditions. Lots of intersections with other trails if it gets too challenging. Some parts are not well traveled so use caution.

hits.name: Copperas and Balance Rock Loop
hits.description: Starting from the Copperas Rock parking, then keep right toward Suspension Bridge. When you get to the bridge, check it out, but continue on same side of stream you were on to Rainbow Falls and Balance Rock. After visiting Balance Rock, retreat a short distance on the trail and take Ledge Trail back to parking area. Ledge Trail has a very nice overlook.

hits.name: Smith's Gap via the Appalachian Trail
Conestoga Trail: Martic Forge to Kelly's Run
hits.description: This route follows the Conestoga Trail which uses Orange Blazes. During your travels you will go past Wind Cave, House Rock Overlook, Tucquan Glen, and Pinnacle Overlook. You can bring your dog, but they must be leashed.

hits.name: Riverwalk Point State Park Waterfront
hits.description:
This is a nice gentle paved waterfront stroll with good views of the bridge.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Commonwealth Place at the southwest end of the trail. Two of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete. It is typically at least 5 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Eagle's Nest via Sand Spring and Tom Lowe Trails Loop
hits.description: From the PA State Game Lands 110 parking lot on Northkill Road proceed up a Game Lands service road past the gate. Bear left off road onto the Sand Springs Trail (blue blazes). Sand Springs Trail crosses Northkill Creek, following a stream up the mountain. At 1.9 miles from parking lot reach a junction with the Tom Lowe Trail beside the rock walled Sand Spring. Sand Springs Trail continues to the right and reaches the AT in 0.1 miles. Bear left onto AT and continue for 1.1 miles through game commission burn areas. Trail is quite rocky for long stretches. Reach junction with old game commission service road. Bear left onto Eagles Nest Trail. This trail was recently over-laid with a game commission service road. Follow the blue blazed footpath where the road diverges. In one mile reach the Eagles Nest lookout. a plaque at the lookout dedicates the foundation of the Blue Mountain Eagle Climbing Club, founded here in 1916. Be advised that rattlesnakes like to occupy the rocks at the lookout in the warmer months. Retrace steps to the junction with the Tom Lowe Trail. Turn onto the Tome Lowe trail (orange blazes), now on the right. Descend steeply from the ridge before reaching a stream and bearing left. At 8 miles cross stream on wooden bridge. Keep an eye out for orange blazes. Reach Northkill Creek at 9 miles. Trail follows creek upstream back to parking lot.

hits.name: Ridley Creek Southern Trails Loop
hits.description: Southern half of the park's trails. First half is pretty flat, second half is more up and down.

hits.name: Shikellamy Overlook Trail
hits.description:
A simple walk in a small state park, nice view

This small State Park has a easy walking path with a nice view of the Susquehanna River valley

hits.name: Black Oak Savanna, Whitetail Crossing, Duck Run, West Overlook, Timber, and Transition Trails Loop
hits.description: The offline map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that the trail is not marked well.

hits.name: Lake Lenape to Wolf Rocks via Appalachian Trail
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Delps to Blue Mountain Ski Area
Barbour Rock via West Rim Trail
hits.description: A bit more than 5 miles out and back. Mild uphill from the trailhead parking area to Barbour Rock, then back down. There are a few water crossings (via footbridges) that are nearly dried up by mid season (July).

hits.name: McDade Trail South
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Bear Creek Preserve Waterfall and Purple Loop
hits.description: This is a loop trail with a couple of waterfalls. Well marked trails, but pay attention for them. Can be linked with other trails on the Preserve for a longer hike.  There are a few decent uphill climbs, but nothing that is too strenuous.

hits.name: Black Rock Sanctuary Nature Trail
hits.description:
Nice trail! Paved and clean with a nice water view in the center. There are lots of activities for young children set up along the trail with educational opportunities in each one.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Black Rock Road at the northwest end of the trail. Two of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is boardwalks (with railings), pavement, or packed gravel, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) downhill and uphill sections in about the first 0.25 miles when going clockwise. 

Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Tebolt, Brocker, and Hess Trails Loop
Mount Davis Highpoint Trail
hits.description: This trail takes you to the Pennsylvania highpoint without the rest of the loop.

hits.name: Rocky Knob Trail to Long Pine Run Reservoir
Blue Dot Trail, Appalachian Trail, Iris Trail Loop From Sawmill Lake
hits.description:
This is a hike from Sawmill Lake Campground. The Blue Dot Trail starts at the campsite. If you are not staying at the campground there is a 2-car parking pullout at the trailhead but you should check at the park office if not. 

Once you are close to the top, you will get a nice westward view overlooking Sawmill Lake. The Blue Dot trail ends at Appalachian Trail which traverses a mountain ridge going south. You will see some nice views to both the West and East, at one point nicely overlooking Lake Rutherford. There is a not-too-long side trail to Rutherford Shelter marked with blue blazes.  You may then return to the AT and follow it to the intersection with Iris Trail which is marked with red dot blazes. 

The Iris trail itself is a rather easy walk to the park office. Before you reach the end of Iris trail there is a short blue trail on the right that will take you to the parking area that is accessible from Rt 23. The Iris trail ends at the intersection with AT and it is a quick hike back to Blue Dot Trail which leads back to the campsite.

Users report that there are bears in this area, so please be alert.

hits.name: Horse Shoe Trail from Valley Forge
Lebanon Reservoir Loop
hits.description: A nice loop around the Lebanon Reservoir.  There are two cable crossings.  This is in a hunting area, so, where orange during hunting seasons.  Nice views of reservoir.  Nice mountain laurel and rhododendron.

hits.name: Springfield Falls
hits.description: Beautiful waterfall, larger than most. This is not really a "trail," because you can park your car in the tiny parking area, cross the road, and then you are right there. However, the woods to the right can be followed down and curves around for different angles of the waterfall.

hits.name: Rattlesnake Creek Road
hits.description: Go after heavy rain for the best effect and wear boots. Take the first left on the trail to find the waterfall, if you hit a Posted sign you've gone too far. There are ropes to assist down a steep descent to the base of the falls. The falls cascade down in half a dozen separate falls with shallow pools between, and are easily climbable with water shoes or boots. One of the best secluded spots in PA!

hits.name: Buck Trail
hits.description:
Buck Trail bisects the Natural Area. Traveling east to west, it is situated on the highest elevations in the park, providing some of the most spectacular views of the valleys to the north. users are truly in the barrens when hiking this trail. The trail also features several abandon mine pits.
 
Road access is available on the west end, while the east end is accessible from other trails that connect it to the parking lot. Chrome Trail leaves the parking lot then connects to Doe Trail, then Buck trail or the extreme end of Buck Trail by way of the Fire Break Trails. The transition from the Doe Trail to the Buck Trail is not identified via a directional sign post or blaze marks; therefore it is important to monitor the map and your location as you proceed.

The trail system can be complicated to first time visitors, but makes for an interesting hike. The Serpentine Barons are definitely different than any other hikes in this general area, and worth a look. The history of the mines adds an element of intrigue.

hits.name: Blue Mountain via Appalachian and Winter Trail
hits.description:
This hike begins with a steep climb from the Lehigh River up to the ridge leading to Blue Mountain.

Enjoy the views along the ridge of the Lehigh Valley.

hits.name: Forest, Appaloosa, and Heritage Trails Loop
hits.description: This trail has a little of everything.  The majority of the trail is in good shape but many areas were very muddy and difficult to walk through.

hits.name: Ridley Creek Red to White Trail Loop
Boyd Big Tree Preserve Loop via Darlington Trail
hits.area_name: Boyd Big Tree Preserve Conservation Area

hits.name: Beechwood Farms Nature Reserve Outer Loop
hits.description:
Beechwood's five miles of trails wind through several distinctive habitats of southwestern Pennsylvania: hardwood forest, pine forest, meadow, and pond. 

The trails are open from dawn to dusk every day free of charge. To help keep Beechwood a special place, please stay on the trails and leave your pets and bikes at home.

hits.name: Settler's Cabin Blue Loop Trail
hits.description: Easy trail, more suited for mountain biking.

hits.name: Larch Tree Trail
hits.description: This is a pleasant walk through an interesting forest. The only hard part about this hike is the walk along the road to the trailhead.  Do not park along the road the rangers have been known to ticket.  Expect to see plenty of wildlife including deer and birds.

hits.name: Back Mountain Trail
hits.description: This hike is a Rails to Trails along the old Lehigh Valley Railroad Company grading that ran between Harveys Lake and Wilkes-Barre. The hike is a very nice walk that enters some woods and runs along Rt 309. You pass Wildcat Falls.

hits.name: Bear Run Orange Loop
hits.description: This is the first of the real hikes (more than a mile or two) in Bear Run, but it's not a difficult hike. Just under 3 miles (4.8 km) and only a 550 ft (168 m) elevation gain over th entire hike, and a fairly gentle gain as well. Good for experienced kids. Dogs on leash welcome.

hits.name: Thunder Swamp Trail
hits.description:
The Thunder Swamp Trail system provides over 40 miles of marked trails to explore in Pennsylvania's Delaware State Forest. 

True to its name, the Thunder Swamp Trail traverses some of the wettest terrain north of the Bayou. This fact, combined with the extremely rocky soil, makes good, sturdy boots an appropriate choice of footwear. If you plan on making this trip in the summer, it is recommended you wear long pants, as mosquitoes, black flies, and deer ticks are abound. By early July, the blueberry bushes have already begun yielding abundant fruit. Although the scenery is nothing spectacular, the heavy deciduous woods and sparsely used trail created a feeling of peaceful solitude.

hits.name: Peter Hausmann Trail at ChesLen Preserve
hits.description: This is a gorgeous trails through meandering meadows. There are some moderate hills, of which the crests of a few offer nice views of the rural landscape. The trail can be used as an out and back from either end.

hits.name: Hopewell Lake to Scott’s Run Lake to Six Penny Loop
hits.description: Visitors have reported that the trails can be hard to follow here so you may want to bring the app or downloaded offline map.

hits.name: Westmoreland Heritage Trail - Delmont Trailhead
hits.description: The Westmoreland Heritage Trail is a paved limestone trail

hits.name: Lower and Upper Juno Loop Via Roaring Brook Trail
hits.description:
Lower & Upper Juno Trail is a section on the North Pocono Trails. It is rated easy to moderate with some steeper climbs on Upper Juno. 
After crossing the Kellum Creek on a stone footpath, Lower Juno offers some beautiful views of this Pocono stream.

hits.name: Painter Rocks to Roaring Run Loop
Kittatinny Mountain and Lunch Rocks Vista via AT
hits.description: Relatively flat easy out and back hike. Very rocky. Two decent views. Lunch Rocks vista is easy to miss as slightly off path.

hits.name: Eliza Fox Trail
hits.description:
Note: The term squaw is considered universally offensive by Indigenous groups in America due to its use for hundreds of years in a derogatory context. Indigenous activists have continued to work both locally and in more general educational efforts, to rename the locations across North America that contain the slur, as well as to eliminate the slur from the lexicon in general. See here for more info: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squaw#Efforts_to_rename_placenames_and_terms_with_squaw_in_them
Old Squaw Trail is a moderately-trafficked trail with termini at the intersection of Squaw Run Road and Hunt Road and across from Beechwood Farms Nature Reserve's parking lot. Much of it follows its namesake, Squaw Run. The trail includes many natural highlights, and the hill grades range from easy to moderate, with the latter mostly located just beyond Riding Meadow dog park.

hits.name: Buzzard Peak via Appalachian Trail
hits.description: Great hike up to Chimney Rocks. The rapid elevation change is not joke, so probably not best for young kids. However, it is short enough to still be very enjoyable.

hits.name: Beaver Pond to Moore's Hill to Mattern Loop
Jakes Rock Overlook
hits.description: As this trail can be narrow and has very steep sections after the first 0.1 miles, it is not marked as wheelchair or stroller friendly. However, some sections of it may be for some users.

hits.name: Beaver Creek Trail
hits.description: Very scenic and lightly travelled trail within Pinchot State Park. Can be muddy in places.

hits.name: Ridgeline Trail Loop
hits.description: PEEC (Pocono Environmental Education Center) is a 501(c)(3) environmental organization in partnership with the Delaware Water Gap NRA. The center sits on top of the Pocono Plateau. You will traverse through Oak/Hickory forests as well as Hemlock Ravines and pass old farm sites.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Caledonia to Pine Grove
Horseshoe, Mt. Misery, Wolfinger, and Valley Creek Loop
Lackawanna State Park Campground
hits.description:
A multitude of different trails to hike or mountain bike. 

Northwoods entrance near the dam can be tricky to find.  It is on left coming from the dam, look for small wooden bridge leading into the forrest Red trail leads to blue and yellow trails which can take you to bullfrog pond.  Orange trails are for mountain bikes.

hits.name: Perkiomen Trail: Perkiomenville to Perkiomen
hits.description:
The Perkiomen Trail, or the "Perky" as it is often called, meanders along the path of Perkiomen creek and can be taken either direction- Oaks to Green Lane Borough or from Green Lane Borough to Oaks. At the southern end, it connects to the Schuylkill River Trail.

Lower Perkiomen Valley Park, Central Perkiomen Valley Park, Green Lane Park, John James Audubon Center at Mill Grove, Pennypacker Mills, and the local Skippack Township trail to Evansburg State Park as well as the towns of Arcola, Collegeville, Schwenksville, Spring Mount, and Green Lane can be accessed via this trail.

hits.name: Middle Creek Short Conservation Trail Loop
Warwick-Ephrata Rail Trail
hits.description:
Nice and decorative wide trail, but there are a lot of road crossings along the way.

Accessibility: This paved trail (with wooden bridges) is estimated to typically be at least 6 feet wide. There are edge barriers and handrails along the bridge sections.

The slope is estimated to typically be moderately steep (8% grade or less) uphill and down. There are estimated to be steep (up to 12% grade) downhill sections at about the 2.9 and 9.4 mile marks when going west. Trail goers using mobility equipment may need assistance in these sections or to avoid them for safety. There is at least 1 designated wheelchair-accessible parking space with an access aisle at the small paved trailhead lot on the east end.

hits.name: Enola Low Grade Trail
hits.description:
The section East of Quarryville is fairly rough - equivalent to a fire or access road in most places with a combination of dirt, grass, large gravel and one section of a hundred or so yards of very thick mud.  But that section is very private.  Around Quarryville the trail becomes a very well-maintained typical rail travel with fine crushed stone and benches spaced throughout for breaks.   A very easy and comfortable ride.  If you're looking for some adventure hit the East section with a mountain bike.  If you want a more casual ride go West from Quarryville.

Accessibility: There appear to be 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of River Road at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. There is at least 1 more designated van-accessible parking spot marked with a waypoint in Quarryville. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at bridges) or natural and potentially soft and uneven, and typically at least 3 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some portions of the paved trail which reduces the width. The most accessible portion of the trail is from the 0.0 through about the 17.7 mile mark. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep to very steep (over 5%) uphill and downhill sections at about 4.8 through 5.0, 7.9 through 8.2, and 28.7 miles when going eastbound. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved, soft, and uneven sections. There are benches and picnic tables along portions of the route for resting.

hits.name: Northwest Lancaster County River Trail: Falmouth to Bainbridge
hits.description: This is a nice hike from Falmouth Access to Koser park in Bainbridge. There is abundant wildlife river views on a well maintained gravel, and a paved trail. This could be a through hike as the trail goes all the way to Columbia, but a shorter option is treating this as an out-and-back trail.

hits.name: Houston Meadow Loop
hits.description:
This loop takes you around Houston Meadow, which is one of the last remaining meadows inside Philadelphia. As you hike, keep an eye out for native and migratory birds, native plants, and other wildlife using this crucial natural habitat. 

Parking is available at Houston Playground, along Sequoia Road. There are restrooms at Houston Playground.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Pen Mar to Ridge Rd
hits.description:
The Mason Dixon Line, Highest AT Peak in MD, Steepest At Grade in MD!

This is part 1 of 4 hikes that could be done as individual day hikes or strung together for a 4 day backpacking trip on the Appalachian Trail to complete the state of Maryland.

This hike begins just north of the Mason Dixon line.  Shortly after passing the Mason Dixon line you enter Pen Mar Park, once an amusement stop along the Western Maryland Railroad.  Portions of the trail follow old rail grades here.   

Almost immediately you begin the ascent of Quirack Mountain, reaching the highest point of the AT through Maryland.  The trail is sometimes rocky and slow going, but most of the way is well cleared and smooth.  This section also boast the steepest grade of the AT in Maryland and you will be going UP, but it is fortunately for just a short distance.

A nice spring/stream serves Ensign Cowell shelter, which you can make your first night's destination, or push on just 2/10 of a mile to Wolfsvill Road, where there is room to park a second car if day hiking.

hits.name: Turtle Trail Loop
hits.description: This is a nice, quiet, well marked and maintained hike if you’re looking for a long walk in the woods (not very scenic except for usual forest vegetation) with a light amount of elevation change. This trail is pretty simple without steep hills or rocks and gets a good amount of mountain bike traffic.

hits.name: Mingo Creek Paved Path
hits.description:
This trail is used by locals on a daily basis for exercise. It is highly trafficked by walkers, runners, and bikes. It is one of those small-town parks where everyone says hello as they pass. The only hill is up by the dog park. There may not be cell phone service within the park.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the small unpaved parking lots off of Mingo Creek Road at the west end of the trail. There are designated wheelchair-accessible restrooms at the west end of the route. There are at least 3 van-accessible parking spots with striped access aisles in the paved lot marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges), smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 2.8 miles heading eastbound. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections at about 1.1 and 2.9 miles when going eastbound. The typical cross slope is 2% and the max is 5%.

Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Highspire Reservoir Trail
hits.description:
This is a gentle out and back that is great for the whole family. This trail is open all year and offers a vastly different look during each season including a diverse display of birds, reptiles, and mammals. A highlight of springtime is the many very large snapping turtles that sun themselves in the waters. 

Please note that you can access this trail from either direction because there are city parks at both ends.

Accessibility: There is 1 unlined designated accessible space in the gravel parking lot off of White House Lane at the east end of the trail. It is not van-accessible with striped access aisles. There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Catherine Street at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is gravel or wooden boardwalk with edge barriers or railings. It is typically at least 5 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

hits.name: Salt Springs Loop Trail
hits.description:
* 405 acres 
* Towering old growth hemlock trees, many estimated to be over 300 years old, 
* Rocky gorge cut by Fall Brook with its three waterfalls. 
* 300 acres adjacent to the park's southern border, is also open for public access.

12.75 miles of trails in total. The longest loop is just under 5 miles and is comprised of a few different trail segments. A project to blaze new trails in recently acquired, adjacent properties, should lengthen the mileage.

The trails pass through old growth forest, overlook the gorge and meander through various habitats.

hits.name: Hawk Mountain via Skyline and Appalachian Trail
Culps Hill
hits.description:
Dogs are not allowed inside the cemetery, building or museum. Off line map is recommended to get oriented as several users have reported that this trail is not well marked. Please consult the Park's map to orient yourself as signage is very poor in this area. 
https://www.nps.gov/gett/planyourvisit/maps.htm

hits.name: Climbers Run Nature Preserve Loop
hits.description: The trail is not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is recommended.

hits.name: Witch Hazel Trail via Great Allegheny Passage
hits.description:
Open dawn to dusk year-round. 

A scenic and beautiful hike along the river. A perfect mix of trails that are navigable and safe yet adventuresome. There’s some gorgeous art on the ruins near the start of the Witch trail.

hits.name: Shiloh Road Spring Creek Canyon Loop
North Park Hybrid Loop Trail
hits.description: From the Pie Tranor field parking lot, start at trail head due east towards the sign for Fawn shelter and follow the red blazes. Follow until you reach S. Ridge Rd. and walk along until you see the white blazes. Follow along the wider portion of that trail, then follow the black to orange/red.

hits.name: North Country Trail: PA 346 to PA 321
North Country Trail: Bowtown to Darlington
Ridenour and Hawn’s Overlooks
hits.description:
This is a short gravel trail going to 2 beautiful overlooks of Raystown Lake. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Henderson Overlook Road at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is gravel. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the Ridenour Overlook in the first about 0.1 miles. The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade beyond about 0.1 miles. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Perkiomen Trail around Green Lane Reservoir
Darlington Trail to Rocky Run Trail
North Country Trail: Lucinda to Kellettville
Cherry Springs Loop
hits.description: This is a great hike for winter conditions. You can see a few waterfalls without having to do the really narrow and icy trails elsewhere in the park. The second half of the loop is along the river. Both the Cherry Run and Mountain Springs trails are blazed with red and considered to be "More Difficult" by the park.

hits.name: Rose Gardens Loop
hits.description:
This is a paved loop around the Rose Gardens. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Parkway Boulevard at the northwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, concrete, brick, or wooden bridge with railings. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Tuscarora Trail - Cowans Gap to Tower Rd
hits.description: Directions are pretty straightforward as to how to follow this trail. As long as you follow the blue blazes of the Tuscarora Trail here you will not get lost on a side trail. There are many side trails that lead back to Cowans Gap State Park but just keep following the blazes.

hits.name: Sterner Mill and Old High Bridge Trail
Money Rocks and Welsh Mountain Nature Preserve Loop
Deer Trail, Hilltop Trail, Maconaquah Trail Loop
Canoe Lake and Beaver Pond Trail Loop
Montour Trail: Venice to Hendersonville
hits.description:
One of the more heavily trafficked sections of the Mountour Trail because of Cecil Park, this crushed limestone 5 mile rail-trail features the National Tunnel. 

Below Hendersonville, there are several incomplete sections of the trail, so you will have to take an on-road bypass to get to Thompsonville and the section of the Mountour known as the Arrowhead Trail.

hits.name: Pinnacle via Blue Rocks Campground Trail
hits.description: Fastest way to get to the Pinnacle via Blue Rocks Campground access trail.  Trail is located in the Blue Rocks Family Campground in Lenhartsville PA, not Lebanon Kansas as written at the top of this page. There is a fee to use the trail. Pay at the campground office.

hits.name: North Park White/Orange Dot Trail Loop
Plainfield Township Trail
hits.description:
Parking lots are available at both trailheads. The trail used to be a railroad for the slate quarry. The trail crosses Little Bushkill Creek five times on scenic wooden bridges from West Pen Argyl to the outskirts of Stockertown on a slight downhill grade. It follows the creek for a while too. All but the northern segment is paved. The trail is open from dawn to dusk.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Center Street at the south end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel with some bumps. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 1.6 and 7.9-8.1 miles when going north. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: Cumberland Valley Overlook via Darlington Trail
hits.description: 3.8 mile out and back, moderately traveled portion of the Darlington Trail that connects with the Appalachian Trail and access to Darlington Shelter and Cumberland Valley Overlook.  Plenty of parking at trailhead on Miller’s Gap Road.  Most of the trail is in state game lands so orange clothing is recommended during hunting season.  Dogs are allowed on this trail.

hits.name: Theodore A. Parker III Natural Area
hits.area_name: Theodore A. Parker III Natural Area

hits.name: Roaring Run Trail
hits.description:
The trail is rated as moderate because of a gradual elevation change and numerous stream crossings.

The Roaring Run Trail follows Roaring Run, which is a spring-fed mountain stream, from its source at the base of Laurel Ridge almost to its confluence with Indian Creek.

The trail proceeds eastward from the trailhead.  After about 0.25 miles, the trail meets the South Loop Trail.  The Roaring Run Trail proceeds northeast from this trail junction and makes the first of many crossings of Roaring Run after about another mile.  The trail crosses Roaring Run a total of twenty-eight times and also crosses several secondary streams.  None of the crossings have bridges, but crossings are generally shallow enough that a hiker with proper footwear can just walk across.  After 3.3 miles, the trail meets the Hillside Trail.

Roaring Run itself is an archetype of a Pennsylvania mountain stream with beautiful small cascades, moss-covered sandstone boulders, hardwood forest and wildflowers.

The trail can also be hiked east-to-west from the parking lot at the junction of the Roaring Run and Hillside Trails.

hits.name: Watres Falls
hits.description: Accessing the falls involves crossing the creek, be prepared to get your feet wet!

hits.name: Life, Flight and Kidney Stone Trail
hits.description: This is a well maintained trail by Geisinger Hospital. It has been noted portions fo this trail are eroded and rerouted.

hits.name: Coal Knob to Tuttletown
hits.description: This is primarily a mountain biking trail. Proceed with awareness and caution if using the trail to hike or run.

hits.name: Boxer’s Trail
hits.description: This is a beautiful trail with some neat historical significance. It’s a piece of Philly sports history. Good for trail running, walking and even bikes. You'll have nice views of the river throughout the path.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Shippensburg Road to Caledonia State Park
Scenic Gorge Trail
hits.description: PEEC (Pocono Environmental Education Center) is a 501(c)(3) environmental organization in partnership with the Delaware Water Gap NRA. The center sits on top of the Pocono Plateau. You will traverse through Oak/Hickory forests as well as Hemlock Ravines and pass old farm sites.

hits.name: Laurel Mountain State Park via Laurel Highlands Hiking Trail
hits.description: Hiked between miles 45 and 43 on the LHHT.   Love mammoth rocks, mountain laurel-rhododendron, and hemlocks.  Had to turn back early because of storm but AWESOME HIKE!!!!!

hits.name: Rausch Creek OHV Trail
hits.description:
This area is for off road driving rather than hiking or walking. If using the 4x4 trails, 2 vehicles are needed as they require visitors use a buddy system. 

Rausch Creek Off-Road Park is devoted to providing a fun, legal place for off-road enthusiasts to go four-wheeling with their four-wheel drive Jeep, truck, or SUV. The park consists of 3,000 acres of easy, intermediate, and difficult trails - featuring rocks, bowls, hills, club friendly trails, and free, on-site camping. There is a two vehicle minimum so do not come alone unless you are meeting a group. Please visit the programs page to learn more about how to find others to go wheeling with: www.rc4x4.org     

Trails are marked similar to ski slopes. Greens aren't very difficult for a capable vehicle, start with those. You need to have CB to talk with trail guide. Beautiful trails and fun climbs and runs. The park does not allow quads, bikes, or side-by-sides. 

Friday and Saturday open for wheeling 8-Dusk
Sunday park closes at 5
Winter hours F/Sa/Su 8-5
Monday-Thursday open by reservation

hits.name: Silver Lake Trail
hits.description: Nice little trail to clear your head for a few minutes. Sometimes it is nice to have any easy trail just to step into nature and listen.

hits.name: Boughton Falls via Oil Creek Trail
hits.description: Park at Jersey Lot or Miller Farm Bridge to access the trail.  This loop travels on both the east and west side of the creek.

hits.name: Tekening Blue Trail
hits.description: A wooded single track trail that runs along the Delaware River and through the woods north of the Martin's Creek Power Plant. The full part offers a jungle gym; recreational fields; native plant habitat; 4 marked trails (markings not always easy to find)

hits.name: Blue Trail to Fireline Trail to Hickory Run Trail Loop
Thick Mountain and Swift Run Trail
Buffalo Valley Rail Trail
hits.description:
There are several road crossings along the way. Wonderful views of surrounding farmland.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Hardwood Drive at the northeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt or crushed stone. It is typically 4 to 8 feet wide. There are metal bollards and gates at street crossings along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily. 

There is a double track along some of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate. The most accessible portions of the trail are the paved sections at either end. 

The entire trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms along the trail.

hits.name: Forest Hill, Forge, Lake, and Cedar Hollow Trails Loop
North County Trail: Wampum Chapter
hits.description:
This is the first 2.6 miles of the North Country Trail - Wampum Chapter that starts on Rt. 251 right at the OH/PA line.  The Wampum Chapter did a GREAT JOB setting up the trail head. There is a big sign, a box with a trail log and maps, and even a graveled parking section.  The hill climbs aren't too bad at all and most of this section is pretty flat or on a low grade incline. 

The middle part of this hike takes you across a field that bursting with wildlife - from butterflys and big ant hills to deer and rabbits.  The trail is well maintained and marked.  Navigating it will be no trouble at all.  Enjoy!

hits.name: Mason Dixon Trail via Highpoint Park
Oil Creek Bike Trail
hits.description:
This trail is an old narrow gage rail road that was converted to a bike trail that travels along the creek. Unfortunately, here are no waterfalls along the bike trail. but, it still packs some beautiful views along the route.

The bike trail is between Petroleum Centre and Titusville's Drake Well (Jersey Lot).  You can also access the bike trail from Miller Farm Bridge.  This can be fairly heavily trafficked especially near the two trail heads and the center where the trail is accessed.

hits.name: Orange, Blue, and Paved Trail Loop
hits.description: Visitors have reported that the trail is not well marked so you may want to bring the app or downloaded offline map for directions.

hits.name: Haycock Mountain Loop Trail
hits.description: Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

hits.name: Douglas, Appalachian Trail, and Dunfield Creek Loop
hits.description: The Douglas Trail has dark blue blazes, the Appalachian Trail has white blazes, and the Dunnfield Creek Trail has light green blazes. Most of this trail is wooded but on the Dunnfield Creek section you will be following along and crossing the creek. Brook trout fishing is allowed there.

hits.name: Laurels Run
hits.description: Open to members of the Brandywine Conservancy & Museum of Art with Brandywine membership card. https://www.brandywine.org/conservancy/preserves/laurels-preserve

hits.name: D&H Rail Trail
hits.description:
The Delaware & Hudson Rail Trail (D&H Rail Trail) is a thru trail that starts from the Simpson Viaduct outside of Carbondale, Pennsylvania. At first, it follows alongside the Lackawanna River and runs parallel to the O&W Rail Trail. The path is a mixture of gravel/rough graded trail and smooth stone dust surfaces. There are multiple points of entry along the trail.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Morse Avenue at the south end of the trail. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at bridges), packed gravel, or a natural surface, and typically at least 4 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the mostly unpaved surface type. There are benches along portions of the route for resting.

hits.name: Birdsboro Waters Loop
hits.description:
This route visits the various waters of the Birdsboro Waters Preserve. The trails are decently maintained, but there are no markings and also numerous side/MTB trails that interconnect that do not appear on the AllTrails map layer. Using the app while hiking is advised if you want to follow along.

Note the south part of this highlighted loop that moves away from the dashed route for a bit. The main trail that leads down is a wide gravel path, but if you take the side trail as highlighted here, you will follow down in parallel closer to the nice stream all the way down with some mountain-laurel along the way.

hits.name: Jennings Environmental Education Center Trail Loop Trail
hits.description:
This is a really nice and well-maintained trail. The trail has beautiful all-around scenery. 

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of 528 at the southeast end of the trail. The trail surface is a natural surface (dirt, grass, rocks, roots). It is typically at least 6 feet wide.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections from about 0.6-0.8 when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade.

hits.name: West Penn Trail
hits.description:
Rail trail west from Saltsburg needs a lot of work (5 miles).

The mile of trail through Saltsburg is fine surface trail and freatured a number of interpretive signs about live in this important canal an rail town when the salt wells drove the economy. North Park, featuring the location of Lock #8 of the Pennsylvania Mainline Canal is on the National Register of Historic Places.

North of the bridge over Blacklegs creek, however, the trail is undeveloped. Puddles, ruts, ditches and the like are for the next mile. After that, the trail runs along abandoned rail and so isn't too bad. Then, after the Avonmore Rail Loading Yard, it's is a paved private road. 

While this section of trail is in some of its earliest stages, long term hopes are to connect to the Roaring Run Trail and then beyond all the way to the Allegheny River 20 miles downstream.

For now, though, this needs a lot of work.

hits.name: Mill Creek Trail to Raccoon Trail Loop
Appalachian Trail: Peters Mountain to Clarks Valley
Magnesium Spring and Black Spring Loop
Switchback, Pisgah and Upper Switchback Loop
D & L Trail from Black Diamond Trailhead to White Haven
Maple Springs Loop and Corrigan Walkway Loop
Flight 93 National Monument
hits.description:
This trail loops around the Memorial. It starts and ends at the northwest end by the visitor center. There is another a parking lot, visitor shelter, and paved section of trail in the southwest corner off of Skyline Road.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Approach Road at the northwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is smoothly paved with cement, stone, or gravel. It is typically 4 to 8 feet wide with many wider passing spaces. There is an uneven cross slope that may be difficult to navigate. The most accessible portions of the trail are the paved sections. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) but there are steeper sections at about 0.8 and 2.0 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the gravel surface type and grade. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms. The visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: The Blue Burn
hits.description: This trail can only be hiked clockwise and is part of the Blue Mountain Resort. There is a lodge and bar found along the well developed trail.

hits.name: Rachel Carson Trail: West from McKinney Road
Laurel Highland Hiking Trail: Grindle Ridge to Rt. 31
hits.description:
Scenic trail through Seven Springs resort & two springs along the way. (7 miles)

The yellow-blazed Laurel Highland Hiking Trail covers 70 miles from Ohiopyle State Park north to Seward. This review covers the 6.6 mile section between the Grindle Ridge Shelter Area and PA Route 31.

This section of trail cuts right through the slopes of the Seven Springs Ski Resort. Once the snows are gone, so too are the people and you have the slopes all to yourself. And it's not called Seven Springs for nothing. There are two springs near the trail, one of which burbles out of the ground an arms-length off the trail. The resort uses the springs to fuel their snow making machines during the ski season but you can use them to replenish your water supply as it can get hot on the exposed slopes.

Just North of the Grindle Ridge Shelters where the trail crosses Blue Hole Creek is an excelent place to sit on a rock and soak your feet in the crisp waters. Even in the summer the water is probably too cold to imerse more than that.

hits.name: Bryn Coed Preserve Yellow, Purple and Red Trail
Appalachian Trail: Clark's Creek to Greenpoint
hits.description:
This is another nice section of trail to hike.  There's plenty of access to water.  Along the way you can see the Yellow Springs ruins and a sign marking the location of the Village of Rausch Gap.  

The hiking is easy to moderate.  There weren't a lot of hills.  Like most of the AT in PA, there were parts of this section that were rather rocky.

hits.name: Horseshoe Trail, Explorer Lodge, Spring Trail, and Hammer Creek Road Loop
Penndel Trail North from London Tract Meeting House
Rocky Ridge Perimeter Trail
hits.description:
This trail around the perimeter of the park starts at Trail 5 and finishes out on trail 7. 

A fun hike with a mix of flat and rolling ups and downs. There are two observation decks for great views along the way.

hits.name: North Country Trail: Henry’s Mills to Kellettville
hits.description:
This is another beautiful section of the North Country National Scenic Trail in the Allegheny National Forest. The path takes you though old oil drilling areas along abandoned grades and some forest roads. The highlights include old equipment ruins and beautiful creek valleys.

The trail starts with a moderate climb of about 500' in a little over a mile and the remainder of the hike consists of rolling hills as you walk into various creek valleys and small ridges. Dispersed camping and trail side shelters and are available at multiple locations. The center of the trail shares a short section of the Minister Creek trail and its Triple Fork camping areas. Water is available every few miles.

Parking is at either end of the trail section. There is a pull off on RT666 along Tionesta creek just south of the bridge at Henry's Mill. On the Kellettville end of the trail, there is a parking lot across from the campground entrance.

hits.name: Poplar Grove Trail to White Tail Deer Trail to Red Trail Loop
House Rock Nature and Ralph Goodno Trail
Wolf Swamp and Deep Lake Trails Loop
Schuylkill River Trail: Parker Ford to Cromby
hits.description:
This trail is half gravel or half paved. The unpaved sections have a stone dust base that is good for walking, running, and cycling. It is well-kept and runs along the Schuylkill River with many sections directly behind rows of homes and factories. There are several road crossings necessary to fully navigate the trail, so please use caution.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Linfield Road at the north end of the trail. However, there is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Gay Street at about 3.6 miles when south. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. This parking lot has been marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. There are metal gates or bollards at street crossings which reduces the width temporarily. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 1.0 and 6.0-6.2 miles when going south. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: Handsome Lake Campground via Tracy Ridge
hits.description: Nice trail, awesome campground. Campground is self pay $12 a night. Picnic tables, tent spots, well water, toilets and fire rings.

hits.name: Pleasant Valley Trail
hits.description: This is a mostly off-road run on cross country ski trails with about a half mile of paved road. The scenery is beautiful and there's abundant wildlife.  Marked with blue paint markers along the way.

hits.name: Tuscarora Trail: Colonel Denning to Millers Gap Road
Tiadaghton, Tower, Ramsey and Mid-State Trail
Wilson Park Trail
hits.description:
This is a paved trail that is great for running, cycling, and walking. There is tons of car parking at the park, but very little shade along the path. There are benches and open grass space along the way too.

Accessibility: There are 6 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Wilson Road at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Pine Grove Furnace: Appalachian and Pole Steeple Loop
Kentuck Trail to Youghiogheny River Trail Loop
Great Allegheny Passage: Waterfront to Riverton Bridge
hits.description:
There are wonderful waterfront views along this paved trail.

Accessibility: There are 16 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of East Waterfront Drive at the northwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, concrete, or wooden bridge with railings. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 1.8 and 5.5 miles when going southwest. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Bruised Ego, Stone Henge, Waterfall, and Blueberry Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Dick and Nancy Eales Nature Preserve

hits.name: Mason-Dixon Trail South from Southbank Road
Great Allegheny Passage: Sutersville to West Newton
hits.description:
The Great Allegheny Passage was once called the Yough River Trail. Crushed limestone surfaced rail-trail along the Youghiogheny River. (4 miles)

Typical rail-trail conversion with an even and level surface of crushed limestone.

Just north of the West Newton is a rebuilt replica of the rail station that once stood here and a combination rail car (combination of passenger and baggage) built in 1925. This will become the new headquarters of the Regional Trail Council.

This section of trail features two sets of mile markers. The original P&LE  markers measuring rail miles to Pittsburgh and the new plastic Great Allegheny Passage merkers for trail miles to Cumberland.

hits.name: Old Laurel Run, Charcoal Flats and Spruce Gap Loop
