Nolde Forest Outer Loop
hits.description: There are restroom facilities along the routes and are marked along the park trail maps.  This outer loop offers a lot of hills, which is great for stepping up your cardio.  Beautiful park with so many trails and beautiful sights to offer.

hits.name: Glen Park Trail
hits.description: Hiking trail 1 mile long that runs along Broadhead creek with multiple mountain bicycle paths going uphill.

hits.name: Great Allegheny Passage: West Newton to Cedar Creek
hits.description:
The Great Allegheny Passage was once called the Yough River Trail. Rail trail past a vast, abandoned mine complex into Cedar Creek Park.

The most prominent feature of this section of the Youghiogheny River Trail is the abandoned Banning No.4 Mine. Most of the structures have been torn down but one structure remains and continues to operate. The pumping and filtration station is processing 8 million gallons of mine runoff a day to protect the Yough River ecosystem.

The scenery improves dramatically as the trail continues South into Cedar Creek Park.

This section of trail features two sets of mile markers. The original P&LE  markers measuring rail miles to Pittsburgh and the new plastic Great Allegheny Passage markers for trail miles to Cumberland.

hits.name: Snowy Mountain and Chimney Rock via AT
Thun Trail
hits.description: This is a flat gravel trail starting in Reading, Pennsylvania and continues along the Schuylkill River.

hits.name: Hearts Content National Scenic Area Trail
North Clayton Trail to South Clayton Trail Loop
Dennison Point Overlook, Kennerdell and River Trail Loop
Keystone Lake Loop
hits.description:
This is a nice, mostly paved trail in a well-maintained park. 

Accessibility: There do not appear to be designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Slag Road at the northwest end of the trail. 
The trail surface is paved or packed gravel and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less), except for steep (8-12%) sections at about 0.4 miles uphill, 0.6 miles downhill, 1.0 miles downhill, and 1.7-1.8 miles uphill when going counterclockwise. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: Radnor Trail
hits.description:
This is a nice and well-maintained community trail. It’s just a paved path with gravel on the side that’s pretty well-shaded. It is suburban with houses and communities and fences on either side of you. It is an old rail trail, so no spectacular views or flora/fauna to explore. While this trail bridges over many major roads, there are still road crossings along the way, so please cross safely. 

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Old Sugartown Road at the west end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. Additionally, there are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Conestoga Road at about 1.8 miles when going east. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. This parking lot has been marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.6, 2.0, and 2.2-2.3 miles when going east. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: Bear Paw, Overlook Ridge, Shaffers Way, Pond View and Critters Run Trail
Blue Marsh Loop Trail
hits.description: Awesome peninsula, wide-open meadows, corn field, and a soybean field.  Cool lakeside stop in the middle. Strollers and wheelchairs may be able to do part of this trail, but there are grass and steep sections that would likely be too difficult.

hits.name: Hawk Watch Loop
hits.description: Starts at Hawk Watch in Fort Washington State Park.  Up hill through camp site, across road to trails with very few people, back around to disc golf area and along train tracks to Hawk Watch.

hits.name: Top Mountain Trail
hits.description: If you visit this trail in the winter or after rain, a 4-wheel drive vehicle is recommended.

hits.name: Laurel Highland Hiking Trail: Jersey Hollow Rd. to Conn Rd
hits.description: The yellow-blazed Laurel Highland Hiking Trail covers 70 miles from Ohiopyle State Park north to Seward.

hits.name: John P Saylor Trail
hits.description: Very flat, great beginner backpacking trip.  Muddy and rutted from ATV traffic

hits.name: Lake Border Trail
hits.area_name: Blue Marsh Lake National Recreation Area

hits.name: Sandy Creek Trail
hits.description:
This is a paved trail that is great for walking or cycling. There are no bathrooms available along the route. 

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Fishermans Cove Road at the west end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 4.6, 6.0, 6.2, and 7.4 miles when going east. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: Schuylkill River Trail: Port Providence to Upper Schuylkill Valley Park
Appalachian Trail to Pinnacle Trail to Furnace Creek Trail Loop
Standing Stone Trail and Tuscarora Trail Loop
Ravine and Gray Fox Trails Loop
Trout Island Trail
hits.description:
This is a leisurely paved path through the woods with some dirt trails leading down to the water and a nice view of the dam. Please be aware that there is a hunting area close by.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved street parking off of Mercer Avenue at the southwest end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section in the first about 0.1 miles when going northeast. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Hopewell Fire Tower via Boone Trail
Bowman Hill
hits.description: There is a $6 fee to enter the wildflower preserve and a $7 fee if you want to climb the tower.

hits.name: Mount Tom Loop
hits.description: Start at Darling Run Parking lot by the bathrooms. Look for the Mt. Tom trail sign with yellow blazes. Take this and cross the road and look for the yellow blazes to the right. You will cross a stream before you begin the main climb. When you come to the fire road there is a fork. One option is to take the steep trail (yellow blazed) .6 Miles to the top. The other option is to take the fire road (red blazed) 1.5 Miles to the top. You can make a loop if you take either up, taking the other one down. Be observant on the fire road since some of the red blazes are faint.

hits.name: Minshall and Pink Hill Trail
hits.description:
Tyler Arboretum is a historic property comprising 650 acres of gardens, woodland, creek valleys, and meadows. Six marked trails range in length from 1.5 to 7.9 miles and are ideal for day hikes and trail running. A 1.3-mile paved loop is suitable for strollers. Tyler Arboretum is a private nonprofit that relies on admission fees, membership fees, and private donations to maintain its 17 miles of hiking trails.

Entrance to the arboretum is via the parking lot and visitor center at 515 Painter Road, Media, PA 19063. Check www.tylerarboretum.org for opening hours and additional information.

Daily admission: $15 for adults, discounts available for children and seniors. Free to Tyler Arboretum members.

No pets allowed. Bicycles and all motorized vehicles are prohibited.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Wind Gap to Smith Gap
Campbell's Ledge
hits.description: Although private property, this trail is open to the public for hiking and hunting by a PA Game Commission Cooperative. When passing through private property easements and right-of-ways it is especially important to stay on the path and respect posted guidance. Local officials and private landowners work in partnership to provide public access to this area. Staying on the path while on private property ensures that agreements between local officials and the landowner are upheld and that this trail remains open to the public in the future.

hits.name: Dark Hollow
hits.description: Park at the old bridge over Neshaminy Creek, off of old York Rd.  Out & Back path toward Dark Hollow Rd.

hits.name: Standing Stone Trail: Butler Knob to Throne Room
hits.description:
4 of the most stunning Vistas along the Standing Stone Trail, are in the two mile segment on Jacks Mountain from Butler Knob to the Throne Room. This makes for a moderate hike along the ridge without large elevation gains. This is an alternative to get to the Throne Room by taking Jacks Tower Road, rather than Jacks Mountain Road. Both roads are in rough shape, but this route doesn’t have cliffs on the edge. SUV and Trucks can make it up to the Knob, would not recommend in a car. There are also options to park lower and hike up to the Knob as well. Parking is right at Jacks Fire Tower. 

The trail is lightly trafficked but is well-marked with red/orange stripes on trees and rocks.

hits.name: Enola Low Grade Trail Short Out-and-Back
Appalachian Trail: Blue Mountain House Road to Bake Oven Knob
Elders Run, Middle Creek, Volunteer, Fireline, to Forest Demo Trail Loop
hits.description: Elders Run is the only designated path on this loop where bikes and horses are permitted.

hits.name: Lower Trail to Deer Path Loop
McDade Trail North
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: US30 to Rocky Mountain Camp
Chapel Trail
hits.description: This tree-lined trail is mostly flat and follows alongside train tracks for the first half. It also passes by an old cemetery, eventually climbing to views of the Schuylkill River before ending at Washington's Headquarters.

hits.name: Ridley Creek State Park Horse Loop
Montour Trail - Enlow to Boggs
hits.description:
Steady rail-trail climb.  (4 Miles)

The section of the Mountour Trail from Imperial South is an unchararasticly steep climb for a rail-trail. Steep is perhaps an overstatement for something that doesn't exceed an 8% grade but it is a noticibly steady climb into strip mine territory.

Thankfully, the mines of this area have been pretty well reclaimed.

hits.name: Stairway Lake Trail
hits.description: Please note you may encounter rattle snakes on this trail.

hits.name: Muhlenburg Rail Trail
hits.description:
This is a nice paved trail with ample parking at both ends. It is great for walking or cycling. There are several road crossings necessary to fully navigate the trail, so please cross safely. 

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Mount Laurel Road at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Montrose Avenue at the south end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. There are metal bollards at street crossings along the trail which reduces the width temporarily. The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Springfield-Swarthmore Loop
hits.description: Great running/hiking trail to see the overall landscape of both the Springfield Trail and Leiper-Smedley Trails! Takes you from Springfield to Swarthmore and back (never retraces its route).

hits.name: Jere Knight Nature Trail
hits.description: This is a well-maintained and clean educational trail, with limited parking. This trail closes during deer hunting season from 9/18 to 1/29 (with the exception of Sundays), so please check ahead before visiting.

hits.name: Hawk Point Overlook via Rhododendron Trail
hits.description: Hawk Point is a nice overlook of the Susquehanna River. It's definitely a must-see for anyone driving through the area! There is a road that leads directly to the overlook that allows it to be wheelchair accessible. There are a few trails, most of which are marked easy but have moderate inclines.

hits.name: Lackawanna River Heritage Trail
hits.description:
This trail is paved, mostly gentle in slope, and well-maintained. It heads from south Scranton to Taylor and back.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the small paved parking lot off of East Elm Street at the northeast end of the trail. One is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Ziegler Preserve and Gardner Spencer Preserve Loop
Emerald View and Grandview Parks Loop
hits.description: This loop track takes in both the urban skyline and flavor of Pittsburgh, along with miles of singletrack trails nestled on Mount Washington.

hits.name: Port Providence to Lock 60 via Schuylkill River Trail
hits.description:
This is a wonderful trail along a canal/towpath. The Schuylkill River is on one side and the canal on the other. There is a lot of greenery in the warmer months. This route is popular for cyclists and kayakers. Birds such as ducks and geese can be spotted in the canal. 

This is a short section of the Schuykill River Trail which continues in both directions from the parking area. The trail can be slightly wet or muddy on rainy days but is very solid soil and crushed stone mix. It is nice for gravel biking.

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Port Providence Road at the southeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is gravel. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type.

hits.name: Plum Dungeon Falls
hits.description: This trail can be hike all year round but, the falls are only visible from mid-October through mid-April. Once the leaves are in full cover, the falls can not be seen. The falls are viewed from across the gorge.  Please do not try to climb down the gorge.  This trail does cross a few creek runs without bridges, so you could possibly get your feet wet depending on the recent rain levels.

hits.name: Pagoda to Peace Rock
hits.description: 1 mike trail from the bottom of the Pagoda along Mount Penn to the Peace Rock painted on a large cliff face on Mount Penn

hits.name: Bald Knob Ridge Trail
hits.description: No bus access. Parking available for 10 cars.

hits.name: Elk Trail
hits.description:
The Elk Trail is a point-to-point trail beginning just outside Benzette and ending on Dents Run Road. Hikers will need to set a shuttle to get back to the starting point, or choose to road walk.

It is about a 9 mile hike on a mixture of gravel and paved roads to make this a loop. The paved roads do not have wide shoulders, so this is not recommended.

hits.name: Jackson Trail
hits.description: Trailhead is a parking area just off PA 26, 2 miles south of Pine Grove Mills.  The trail starts on the east side of the paved road.  Blue blazes.  Follows the ridgeline of Tussey Mountain northeast.  4.5 km into the hike you reach the intersection of Jackson Trail with Mid State Trail.  Turn south and begin following the orange blazes of Mid State Trail.  This portion of the hike heads southwest to the vicinity of Beaver Pond (not visible from the trail) where it intersects with the Pine Grove Trail and the Ironstone Loop Trail.  Turn right, following Mid State back up Tussey Mountain to the start of Jackson Trail.  Sections of the Jackson portion of this hike cross rock fields with little in the way of blazes.  The descent and ascent of Tussey are steep.

hits.name: North Country Trail: PA 346 to ASP 2
Wetlands, Scout and Rachel Carson Trail Loop
Appalachian Trail: Greenpoint to Kimmel Lookout
hits.description:
Good section for a weekend getaway.

This is a fairly nice section to hike.  The trail runs along the top of a ridge and there are a few scenic overviews.  

There are two shelters on this section.  The 501 shelter is very close to the parking lot.  The William Penn Shelter is ~4 miles south of the 501 Shelter.

hits.name: Ernst Trail
hits.description:
A wonderful, mostly paved, trail along French Creek and Watson Run. Picnic areas along the way.

Accessibility: There is at least 1 designated accessible space in the large partially paved parking lot off of Smock Highway at the northeast end of the trail. It is not van-accessible. The trail surface is paved asphalt, wooden bridge (with edge barriers), or gravel. It is typically 4 to 8 feet wide. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 4.0 miles along the pavement. The entire trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Lower Trail to Bald Knob Ridge Trail
Rock Run and Spur Line Trail
State Game Lands Number 203 Loop Trail
Minsi Woods Road Loop
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Out and Back from Smith Gap Road
Conestoga Trail: Kelly's Run to Holtwood Road
Bethlehem South Mountain Loop
hits.description: A challenging trail that takes you through the two mountains located on Lehigh University. Paths are perfect for mountain biking and are popular among local bikers. Trails are also great for hiking and feature abundant native wildlife, plants and trees. There are some nice views towards throughout. This trail is NOT marked, but there is a visible footpath most of the way. You may need to check your phone throughout to stay on this exact path, but feel free to explore the forest!

hits.name: Sunset Rocks from Old Shippenburg Road
Stone Hill Trail
hits.area_name: Eva R. Meng Wildlife Preserve and Bird Sanctuary

hits.name: Boiling Spring and Overlook Trail Loop
Roaring Brook (Red), Sword (Purple), Utah (Blue), and Creekside (Yellow) Loop
hits.description: This loop explores some of the Pocono Trail System within the Elmhurst Tract.

hits.name: Corduroy, Liggett, Deer Meadow, and Heffren Run Trails Loop from Campground
hits.description:
Starting at the campground, take Corduroy Trail. Cross Breezemont Drive and you'll see Liggett Trail.

Take Deer Meadow Trail which will bring you to another campground.

Eventually take Heffren Trail back to Toms Run Road. Cross a bridge, go up some steps, and you'll be back on Liggett Trail, then Corduroy, then back to the campground.
